Ratings.comment: Fantastic teacher! This class is "ungraded", students set their own goals and choose their grades at the end. If you feel you've done a good job and present stuff you put effort into, he's happy to give you an A as long as you participated in class. Content is v. interesting, & lectures are freeform class discussions that are genuinely really fun!
I thought this was a great class, but it was kind of a drag towards the end. A lot of the concepts were interesting to talk about, and he was good about letting everyone talk and discuss opinions.
easy workload, midterm and final were both online with unlimited time, some topics were interesting but lectures could be long and boring

The material is a little difficult to follow and the lectures are a little dry; however, she is very helpful. She offers extra credit on all discussion posts and you know what to expect every week. She posts material kind of late, but since you know what to expect it isnt a big deal. Overall, she is a good teacher.

I was kind of surprised to see her rating not above a 3. I think she is wonderful professor. Her lectures are a little dry, but I blame the pandemic for that. Professor Downing is incredibly nice, but can seem intimidating. She definitely knows her stuff, and it's apparent that she has a passion for philosophy. Not an easy "A", but not hard either

Whoever wrote that last comment has said everything perfectly. I assume it's one of my classmates, since it's for my class as well. Emphasis on the difficult grading and aimless criteria. I've scheduled my next semester philosophy class and made sure not to get her. Lisa is nice as a person, but not a very good professor.

She can't maintain a course schedule and goes off on random tangents often. I usually get very nervous of people like this and for good reason. Her class is the first time I've received a D on a paper in my life. She grades hard without clear grading criteria, and while philosophy is subjective, this is more of an unwarranted attack.

Professor Downing really cares about the material and that is evident in the lectures.  She is not necessarily the most approachable of professors but is incredibly happy when you raise interesting questions in class.

I always want to fall asleep in this class. This is perhaps something to do with me, not the professor. She is a great teacher, just speaks a little bit too slowly and makes the class somehow boring. If you really like philosophy and loves listening to long and slow preachings, go ahead.

Prof. Downing knows the material (early-modern philosophy) extremely well, and she does a good job of teaching with a broad emphasis on time period (for instance, keeping in mind scientific advances). However, she can be repetitive and slow at points. We got behind in class and never really covered all the material that I had hoped.
I hate this class. I fall asleep. The lecture is long and boring and she says uh and um A LOT. Nice lady but the readings are boring as well. She gives notes through a power point and the chalkboard.

Very knowledgable professor but made this course confusing. Reading back on my notes in an attempt to study for the final was like reading a foreign language. Participation is mandatory and there were about 3 people who attended my recitation on a regular basis. She grades papers pretty leniently and exams weren't too difficult.
I didn't enjoy the class, it was boring and I was very uninterested.

If the class was lecture-oriented or on the subject of history of philosophy, Professor Downing would be an excellent professor to have.  But in a discussion-based class, Downing's moderation does not contribute anything to making the students consider philosophy.  Much class time is spent talking about things that are unimportant to the subject.

This class moved along at too slow a pace, and the workload was too light. I felt shorted by a little after having taken this class--like we could have done more and gone in greater depth but didn't. I liked Dr. Downing a lot, though--it's just the course didn't seem to work very well.
boring. not that hard if read sparknotes. will fall asleep in class. final really easy. takes attendance.

The course as a whole was very open-ended, and he was very forgiving with allowing students to drop entire units (if I recall, took s2021). Course as a whole was very writing-heavy, and sometimes you had to be creative with how you presented your work (google drawings for me). IMO As long as you provide reasoning for your answers, it's a breeze.

Recommend this class for philosophy majors specifically. Very tough material, difficult to be made simple even by an excellent professor. Work hard in the papers and exams and read, show up to class, and complete all assignments.

Professor Samuels is very knowledgeable in the field of Philosophy of Mind as well as cognitive psych and the philosophy of cog sci among other related topics. For this reason, class is very interesting, however, the material is quite challenging. Exams and papers are graded hard, you kist out in effort. Show up to class and read the texts.
boring. has a cute dog tho so +1 pt. if you like boring topics about boring things you'll enjoy this class. hes nice and all but like i was so bored.
Lectures occasionally drag, going to recitations really help.

Not necessarily an "easy gen ed". There's gotta be an easier class than PHILOS 2670 out there to satisfy that requirement. It was an interesting class (if you like philosophy) and we had some particularly thoughtful discussions as a class, but man, even at 11am, it was so hard to stay awake listening to Prof. Samuels drone on in his lectures. Hot.

Prof. Samuels is one of my favorite professors. He is very knowledgable and make seemingly hard topics thoroughly explained and very intriguing. He makes students fully engaged into his classroom discussions and interested in philosophy. He grades things a bit too tough, but that is acceptable and helpful. Readings are long but very interesting.

Prof Samuels is a pretty cool dude. His class is what college is supposed to be like. Homework is readings, grades are 2 papers and 2 exams. He doesn't have us doing busy work and that is a good thing. I would say, however, that you do have a responsibility to read. If you do not read- then it will be difficult to follow lecture.

Samuels is incredibly invested in the cognitive neuroscience and philosophy, but his lectures are a bit erudite. I feel lost a good chunk of the time without a background the subject. He tends to ramble sometimes, but he's very funny and personable. Someone that you would like to hang out with outside of class but his lectures are dry sometimes.

For non-philosophy people it was a semi-hard class but otherwise tolerable. GO to class bc he makes the arguments easy to understand. Dont take if cant handle criticism from peers. didnt use the textbook as he posted all the readings on canvas but the readings are pretty long. Grade based on 2 papers, weekly hw responses and 2 exams.

It's a tough class that I wouldn't recommend to non-philosophy majors. Samuels is a really good professor and does a fine job at keeping people engaged. Class is based on two papers and two exams worth 25% each, so it's insanely important to not slip up.

not too bad of a class, kinda hard to follow if you dont get philosophy or dont like the subject. he is pretty funny though and makes class fun. If you do all the readings and go to all the lectures you will get at least a B. graded on 2 papaers that you write, a midterm, and a final. overall not a horrible class but not great either. fairly easy

Very confusing at explaining the material. Don't recommend him for anyone who isn't a senior philosophy major, and even then it's kind of a waste of time because he just doesn't know how to teach. Also totally judgmental and makes terrible assumptions about students and gossips in a rude way. Not a fan of this prof as a person or a teacher.

This class sucks. The material is crazy hard. The good thing is Dr. Samuels is a great guy and really enjoys teaching. He's very open and helpful. I would recommend him as a professor, I just really hated the material in this class.
Good teacher. If you aren't a philosophy major expect to be pretty bored. Easy to get a B. Tough for an A.
He was just an incredible teacher, extremely helpful, very clear and knows his stuff.  If you try, I think it's impossible to get lower than a B+, but getting an A is tough.

His syllabus was a bit more ambitious than we had time for; would've liked a bit more on consciousness, which was our last topic. He's a great teacher, really cares about students' success...and he's hot, which is probably one of the main reasons a lot of us made it to class in the dead winter cold :)

Samuels knows his sh*t, but I think there's some adjustment from semesters to quarters.  We bit off more than we had time to chew in this course.  Readings were assigned but never addressed in class.  He's interested in the material, accessible, and has a lovely British accent. Hard not to think naughty thoughts with this one... he's a hottie.

Dr. Samuels is a visual distraction. Very interesting material; you can get by with occasional class attendance and marginal reading. Highly recommended. Take Advanced Philosophy of Mind if you actually want to learn plausible theories of the mind :)

If you just listen and talk to him and in the class your golden. If you have a lot of other work and ask him for an extension hell give you it. I asked for a short extension and gave me a longer extension than what I asked for.

Very harsh grader. Thought to be a GPA booster but it turn to do opposite. Fail to reach my goal GPA before graduating. His assignments and presentation requirement is very ambiguous or i may say no direction at all. Chose this class because of previous Rate my professor comment. Totally regret it. AVOID his class

He didn't post a single grade until the last day when grades were due, taking TWO months to grade a paper. He said that he would give some sort of feedback but not a single sentence was given. Everything about him was ambiguous (grading, feedback and setup). His grading is very random and you wont know how well you're doing. Avoid him if you can.

He seemed really nice throughout the semester but turned out to be a tough grader. No extra credit or anything to help your grades. I met with him outside of class to review papers but his ambiguous feedback didn't help get a good grade. I disliked the setup of the assignments without rubrics and lack of specific guidelines. Poor class setup.

I thought I was doing well in the class, but I actually didn't know how I was doing in the class since he didn't put in the grades until the LAST day for grade submission! He graded assignments WAY harder than needed to be for a Gen Ed class. Very ambiguous feedback and participation is 10% of the grade. NO CURVE FOR LATE GRADES! RIDICULOUS, AVOID!

2 Papers, a final presentation, and participation are the only grades in the class. Very unclear, no rubrics or grading guidelines. You're only hope is to meet with him outside of class were he gives very vague advice. Doesn't understand his class should be a GPA boost and not one that tears it down. Would not recommend.

Participation is a must. Make sure he knows your name. He offers to meet outside of class for the papers and presentation. Take those opportunities b/c he is very helpful explaining what he wants out of the assignments. His class discussions are insightful and interesting especially the engineering topics. He grows on you. Would take again.

No tests, which is nice. Two 4-5 page term papers and a final group presentation, but he is willing to meet with you to help edit your papers before they are turned in. Participation is vital as discussion is most of the lecture.

Ok so, I took Professor Bertrand for Phil of Religion my first semester and I would recommend his class to literally anyone. There are readings that need to be done, but no daily homework, no participation in class required - although you do have to show up. Tests were four questions, you got a week to do them and you could use your notes.
I loved having him. I never really worried about his class on days I didnt have it. As long as you read the text (which are very interesting) & take notes, you should have no problems in the class.

so many readings for this engineering ethics class. 8 papers in total and you actually need to read all the readings, each around 10ish - 20ish pages to write the paper and he's strict on grading papers. During the weeks that the papers due, I ended up spending more time on this class than on my major classes, which sucked! Not recommended at all

There are a lot of readings that you have to analyze and unpack to answer the homework questions and so many papers that you need to put in excess time into to get a good grade. This class makes me cry every week.
He gives you way too much writing assignments and hes a terribly tough grader. You go to all your lectures do all the reading and put in all the work you still wont get an A on an assessment or exam

At first glance, his grading scheme seems awesome. Then he grades your work. Very unclear about what he would like to have submitted. Always turn in your own work, even in groups. Stresses not doing extra work. Yet, asks vague questions. If you answer the vague questions with vague answers, you dont receive credit for the assignment. DO NOT TAKE
Fun teacher who engages the students with genuine critical conversation. Good person to consult in general, naturally kind and curious, reasonably lenient, cool.
Nice person, difficult professor. Has high expectations for tests and doesn't give very much credit outside of it.

Repeats herself over and over and then is surprised when we don't get through the material. Doesn't like to answer students questions. And, when she does she gives you a response that has nothing to do with what you asked.

Really cared about the material and helping students. The papers, especially the final paper, were difficult but she graded very generously while also providing good feedback. Very difficult if you don't do the readings. She is generous with extensions which was very helpful. I'd recommend this class to anyone, I learned so much!

Professor Howard was a fantastic professor and lecturer. Her class was fairly easy with few assignments but super informative and interesting. Just make sure to do the weekly discussion boards & readings and show up to class because there are in class assignments as well (very rare). She is a pretty easy grader as well.

Great professor. Super interesting stuff. I recommend taking as an easy GE. Not much work. Sometimes in class assignments, so I recommend going to every class and if you don't feel like paying attention you can just do other work. Reading is not necessary for a good grade.

Amazing professor. Lectures are very discussion-based and super interesting. The professor is also super understanding and if you submit your assignment and ask for a deadline she will give one. Would recommend this class and this professor.

Dana seemed really sweet, if not a little scatterbrained. She wasn't the easiest grader, but you can definitely get by with an A. There is a ton of reading assigned and discussed, so you need to learn how to skim and summarize. Overall not my favorite class, but not a bad or overly stressful choice, either.

Dr. Howard is very nice. Her lectures can be boring at times and she does assign a lot of reading. I skimmed the majority of things and did fine. Discussions in class were interesting though. Overall, I liked her. This class was not very hard, just study for the exams and you'll be fine!

Dr. Howard is very passionate about bioethics and it shows in her teaching. She requires weekly discussion posts that have to be at least 300 words long, and her questions can sometimes be hard to have that much to write about. However, she is very nice and knowledgeable about bioethics and very clearly wants all of her students to succeed.
Passionate but gives a lot of readings

Dr. Howard does an amazing job at remaining neutral in discussions of different ideas! I did get frustrated once or twice at unclear grading criteria/questions. If you take the time to do readings, and get the most out of discussion forums youll learn a lot! Also dr Howard is just the sweetest outside of class, and really takes time to answer qs

Professor Howard is very knowledgeable about the topics we discuss, but she is disorganized (does not post assignments until the evening before they are due), and she does not respect her students time (does not end class on time and acts offended when students express this expectation/ timely grading matters).

The class was easy, but lectures were super dry. No midterms or quizzes, just weekly discussion posts and a group project that you get the entire semester to work on. There's a final paper at the end that was pretty easy. Prof. Howard is a super sweet person and is willing to help anyone if you just ask.
Dr. Howard is an amazing professor and incredibly nice! Very easy grader, although is hard to get ahold of. Also low key super cute. Def would take her again as a professor!!!

Howard was a wonderful instructor, enthusiastic and quite approachable.  As others have stated, there is quite a bit of reading-- and not always the easiest material. That should not deter you from taking her class, though; the content is appropriate and engaging nonetheless.   Definitely recommend office hours and participating in-class.

There are lots of readings and slides are long. You need to read the slides to pass exams. In class activity counts for 20%  and reading questions count for 5% and you definitely need that, so attendance is very important. For philosophy class, this one is excellent. You know, it is philosophy

BE READY TO READ! You have to read like 30 pages twice a week and it is very complex english. If you are a good reader, this class should be easy.   There are 2 papers to write and 2 exams. She gives you the questions to the exams before the exam, so that is not that hard.  JUST A LOT OF READING!

There's a lot of reading, but generally you can skim the material and be fine.  She explains the essential information in lecture.  Attendance wasn't mandatory, but there were group projects randomly throughout semester.  She's nice, understanding, and extremely responsive to class demandsideas.  I definitely recommend her.

she is very easy going, go to class and pay a little bit of attention and should be good with an AA-  there is a lot of reading, like a ton, but there are ways to make them shorter.  For the 1st exam she gives you the questions before the exam

She rewards effort. She likes to help students, is very friendly. She relates to students and is very qualified. She is very good at positively reinforcing students and puts attention to detail. I'd love to have her for more classes in the future

Autumn 2013 was her first semester teaching; she received her Ph. D from Brown.                                                        Attendance isn't mandatory, but we did in-class activities that serve to reward those who attend. Discussion is key as well. 4 papers, and a cumulative final for which she provided the questions ahead of time.
Smart Caring Thorough Patient Transparent And with all due respect, hot.
Her classes are not enjoyable, it seems a writing class instead of learning philosophy.
The way she talks is just annoying. She is condescending and I don't know where the grades come from. Don't take her class, useless, learning nothing and not a easy A.

Took this class based on RMP I saw on here. Had a lot of papers and quite a bit of it seemed repetitive and unnecessary. This class was more of a writing class than an ethics class. Thought we'd talk about AI, genetic engineering, etc, but more reading about development of ethics. Don't trust the high rating. Can be condescending (not on purpose)

Dr. Gleason was a good professor who was flexible and seemed to genuinely be concerned about her students. The class could be a bit tough/dry at times given that it was online, but all else considered, she did a good job of keeping it low-stress and well-structured.

Really enjoyed her Engineering Ethics course. She's very willing to answer questions and listen to student feedback. There were a few papers and a number of readings but overall a fair grader and a great teacher.

Dr. Gleason is a competent and thoughtful instructor. While ethics is not my greatest interest, she made classes manageable and the course engaging. Her structure was well suited to the online environment and was very adaptable to feedback from students.

Most gen ed professors are out to get me, but this is the most laid back gen ed I've had at Ohio State, and I still learned a lot, the content is interesting. She adjusted her course midway based on class feedback and is very organized. I recommend her for this class.
she is very helpful when it comes to writing papers. gives great feedback. she turns the class into informal discussions which help introverted students shine.
toughNever take her class again
tough grade, dont trust this high rating grade. Who knows how this grade comes from. Tough!
tough grade both paper and exam

A great teacher. She explains the material in a way that everyone can understand. Not much work for the class, typically one reading quiz per week. Her midterm was very easy if you study the topics that she puts on the review sheet. Wonderful person, always adds in humor during the discussions.

Jennifer is one of my favorite teachers! She helps everyone and always makes sure students understand the topic. She explains things very thoroughly and uses the old, cheaper version of the textbook. There are short homework assignments each class, but the take about 5-10 minutes to complete. She collects sometimes and grades for completion.
jenn is so helpful and such a great teacher!! if you show up to every class you will do fine (you need to show up though). so funny and very accessible outside of class!!

Jenn is extremely nice, and her teaching style is fun and enguaging. She uses the old version of textbooks so I got a PDF of the book for $10 verses $200 for the newest version. If you listen to the lectures and make sure to note the things that she mentions as common mistakes, youll get an A.

Jenn is one of my favorite professors I've had so far. She teaches in a way that is easy to understand and is very helpful when you ask questions. It is very clear that she wants her students to do well. As long as you pay attention in class and do the homework, you will do well in this class.

Jenn was a really good professor. She understood that her class was engineers, so she taught philosophy in a way that engineers could understand it. The class isn't hard and she talks about important and interesting things related to engineering. She is very understanding and wants her students to do well.

Class was more of a discussion then a lecture, participation is part of your grade so try to contribute.  We wrote one paper which she gave good feedback on if you took the time to ask for it.  Tests aren't bad especially if you look over everything briefly, most of the test is writing.  I really enjoyed this class.

She makes you do a lot of reading but the class is mostly just discussion of the readings, so its not like critical that you do the readings. Exams are easy and if you go to office hours for your final paper she will tell you what she wants in a paper.
He is a good professor, I definitely learn a lot on his class. I got easily a A+ because he made his classes enjoyable and he is able to help students when they are struggling. Good choice.
Chulmin Yoon is one of the best instructors that I have had. Had to take this class to fill a GE requirement but it ended up being one of my favorites.

Chulmin is a super nice guy and he really wants everyone to do well. All he asks is that you show up and participate, and if you do, everything else will be super easy. He grades easy and offers some extra credit, the work load is super small, too.
Chulmin is a really stand up guy and is passionate about philosophy. This class is a required GE for engineers but it was pretty enjoyable. The workload was just right for 3 credit hours.

Easiest class at OSU. Chulmin will go at a slow pace, make all quizzes open note, frequently give extra credit, and will walk around during tests and point out questions you answered that "may not be right." As long as you show up to get the notes, you would have to be trying to get less than an A in this class.
This class was by no means difficult. Concepts are easy to understand, and exams are open notes.

Chulmin made this class a really enjoyable one. He is one of the kindest and most helpful professors I have ever had. We were allowed to use notes on tests and got a one sided cheat sheet for the midterm and final. He even brought us cookies from a bakery in the north market for our last class. I loved this man, I wish I could take the class again.

Chulmin is very caring ab students & always very prepared to teach. I thoroughly enjoyed class & wish I could take another w/ him! He gave printouts of the textbook/notes- so buying the book isnt necessary! He prepares you very well if you pay attention/attend atleast the majority of class. He also is very willing to help you understand materials.

He means well, but it was very hard to understand him in the context of this type of material and nothing was ever clear. It was hard to make myself go to class. I only took it so I didn't have to take an actual math class. Take this with a different professor if you can.
a king

Great class to take. Very engaging in lectures. Papers are not too difficult as long as you follow his instructions. Tests are very easy if you read the required material and actually engage in lecture.

Piers is great at making Philosophy interesting and engaging, and often crafts his lectures around group conversation and participation. The only downside is that it can feel disorganized and like its on you to figure out what to study, rather than any clear criteria. If you show up to class and read the material, you should be just fine!

I have to be honest & say that Professor Smith can seem scattered at times, but he definitely makes up for it with his engaging lectures! He's upfront about his grading process, but did not seem to have time to grade papers as they were sent in. He made me challenge what I thought I knew on topics discussed. Great class & material, jumbled prof!
No attendance check. Nice professor.  Easy A. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!
One of the most interesting, engaging professor's I have had. Cares a lot about students actually learning, not about making them struggle for their grade. Highly recommend.
Professor Robinson goes above and beyond for his students. I cannot recommend him enough.

Shabel clearly cared about all of her students and wanted them to succeed. She was very interested and knowledgeable in her subject. Her lectures made what otherwise would have been a difficult subject become fun and easy to understand. Four graded homeworks and three exams.

Shabel's section of 3240 is graded by a TA, so that's one thing to note before taking this course. That being said, her lectures are fantastic and she's always open to dissenting ideas and objections from students. There are 2 exams (short papers and short answer), one long paper, and participation grades. Attend class to understand and do well.
By far one of the best professors I've ever had.
By far one of the best professors at OSU! She is very interested in teaching and class is always interactive and interesting. I definitely recommend this professor.

Professor Shabel is one of the best teachers I've ever had. She made a subject like Symbolic Logic incredibly interesting. Also, she was always willing to take time after class to help you individually if you were confused. Great professor! Take her if you have the chance!

Professor Shabel was a great logic professor. She cares about her students and wants everyone to do well. She seems to really enjoy what she does. Her tests were fair and she curves if necessary. Definitely recommend taking her classes.

Prof Shabel is excellent.  Her lectures are interesting and will keep you awake, she makes her time available to help any student whenever he or she needs, and she really makes you learn, not just regurgitate information.  I would highly recommend any student, philosophy major or not, to take one of her courses!

Very stubborn teacher. It's her way or else it's wrong.  Will meet with you to discuss papers but corrections she makes in paper will later be marked wrong during grading. Class is very interesting and sometimes fun but she can be very close minded.  Write a good 1st paper cause after that she will base your future papers on her judgement from that
FANTASTIC professor! Interesting class; loved her discussion (rather than dry lecture) style. We did a few out-of-class activities that were very fun, and she's a very nice woman.

Shabel was a great teacher. She tried different teaching methods to get the material across. She also made herself available before and after class to answer questions. Shabel always puts bonus questions on tests, so that makes the test less stressful, and the questions are similar to the homework problems. Very good teacher and very good class.
Professor Shabel is awesome. I didn't get an A in her course, but she was always available for help and she made introductory logic as interesting as possible.

Lisa is an excellent professor.  Philo 250 was a difficult course, but she did her best to make the subject matter clear.  I did not enjoy the subject matter, but Lisa is an amazing professor.  She makes herself accessible to all students and she is very interested in helping students. I really like Lisa as a person and a professor.

Great Professor. She always explained everything very well and was willing and able to discuss issues with depth. Had very logical and rational explanations. Provided a really good intro to Philosophy.

I struggled a little with the class because my mind isn't really philosophically oriented, but Professor Shabel was great.  Class was usually pretty interesting and she facilitated some great discussions.  She's extremely helpful in office hours if you  don't understand something or need help on a paper. Make sure to attend class and participate.

Professor Shabel's is an amazing professor! She is very clear and concise, she always has an open mind, and her grading is more than fair. I got a B+ and didn't try all that hard. She really makes the class enjoyable and she has fun teaching. I had a great time in this class. We also watched three movies and she even bought the class pizza once!!
Very clear and gives almost no homework
she's a very good professor. anytime i've had a question about the work she's always made sure to explain it so i understand.

I loved this class.  She's an excellent lecturer who communicates the material clearly while keeping things engaging.  Not only does she go the extra mile to make sure that people understand things, she always stays afterwards when people want to discuss material that is too tangentially related for class.
Great class! She explained the topics very clear and her exams were very fair.

A wonderful professor whose class made me want to change my major. Great at moderating debate and playing devil's advocate. Also a very fair grader with an incredibly light workload. Highly recommended!
Good teacher, tryies to make every example as clear as possible. Also gives a very managable work load.
This class was a breeze.  Only 4 homework assignments and 2 tests that were all very simple.  Highly recommended.
I think this was one of the easiest courses I've taken, and she takes the time to make sure everyone understands the material.
Makes concepts which should be crystal clear very confusing. She has odd office hours, and the homework is very unhelpful
Lectures were very fun and insightful. Easygoing grader too. Only thing is the heavy weekly readings so be smart about it

Literally the worst professor I have ever had. I took the class online and I could never stay awake for the whole lecture... He's a very passive-aggressive grader and his feedback makes you feel terrible. He knows a lot about philosophy but he's not suited to teach a class with an engineering focus.

I took Todd's class entirely online and it was probably my most enjoyable class of the semester. Weekly hw assignments require a lot of reading, but can be done at your own pace throughout the week. Zooms discussed the readings in more detail, which was super useful. Todd is a thoughtful grader and always gave helpful feedback on my papers.

Thought I was taking with another teacher, OSU switched at last second. More of a highschool style teacher/ disorganized. Grades too harsh for how unstructured the class is. Never uploaded lectures on time, which is inconsiderate considering this was an online class, and we can't sit around and wait for every lecture to be uploaded the day of class

Thought I was taking with another teacher, they switched teachers at the last second. Stopped going to class the last few weeks and still passed (I have some previous philo experience). Grades too harsh for the effort he puts forth. His teaching style is highschool level/ disorganized. Never uploaded lectures on time, not good for a online setting.

DeRose is a great professor. There is weekly homework, but it can be done at your own pace. Lots of reading, so keep up on it. There is lots of extra credit opportunities. His exams are reasonable as well. Do what is asked and you will do well in the class.

The professor wasn't the best at explaining the material in lectures. I would have to look up the terms and information online to get more of an understanding. The reading helped me more than the lectures to be honest.

This class is not too hard at all and is super informative for being an intro class while also being intro-level difficulty. Prof. An is very helpful and clearly knows what she is talking about. If you have any suggestions on what would make the class run smoother she is extremely open to them. Overall, very kind but make sure you show up to class.

He's an ok professor. Theres really no lecture, mostly just reading and discussion. its an online course, so we basically would meet on zoom and would discuss the book we have been reading. The class is graded on two main papers only, but Professor Silverman has a very clear grading criteria about his papers, you can even submit RD for feedback.

Goes through two philosophy books but grade is made up of two papers. Make sure to read and be able to participate if asked questions. Turning in papers early and he'll tell you what to fix for an A. Great guy

As an incoming freshman to OSU, Philosophy was the one elective I was interested in taking, and this will be the last philosophy class I will ever take. Professor Silverman was difficult to work with, he would lose emails and did not understand technology, he was angry and bitter, and he is not good at lecturing or even speaking.

Allan is absolutely hilarious in lectures and goes on lots of bizarre tangents, so don't worry about being bored! There is a lot of reading, and he will call on random students to answer questions about the reading, but the class is only actually graded on two papers, which he allows you to correct for an A!

Even online, this class is memorable. Silverman has amazing lectures. He cares greatly about students, and the whole class is graded off 2 papers (but you have to work for it to get an A). He goes on tangents, such as about when he would illegally ride trains as a child in Germany. He's hilarious, caring, smart, and terrifying. Great class!

I took Death and the Meaning of Life for my GE Lit without knowing anything about philosophy. Turns out I hate it, but this class was still fun and interesting due to Allan's stories. Only grades are two papers, which you can get feedback on from the TAs. Was not an easy A for me, but it is definitely attainable when you ask for help.
He is a good professor and very understanding.

I took this class to fulfill my literature GE and im so happy i took it! Allan is enlightening and extremely intelligent. Im so grateful i took this class because of the new persepectives on life I have gained. We only had to read two books and write two papers for the entire class. Overall would recommend!!! 10/10

Genuine and caring professor. His class was easy so long as you went to class or actually read the assigned readings. He basically outlines exactly what needs to be said in his paper to receive an A. If you are interested in the material, then this class will be a breeze for you and you will also end up understanding difficult topics in Philosophy.

Silverman is all-around pretty good. Very tough grader, but definitely willing to help if you seek it out. Kinda a hard-ass, but inspirational at times. Shared some funny digressions about his college roommates and their experiences with LSD.

Great lecturer if you like trying to understand/answer life's biggest questions. Mr. Silverman used Plato's Republic as the book for my class, fall 2016. Grade structure is literally just a midterm paper, a final paper, and extra credit for attendance. Definitely helps to read the book assigned since that's what you write about for both papers.

I took this class as a GE and I honestly did not have much of an interest in Philosophy at all. I went to the first two lectures and stopped going out of boredom. There are only two papers and the topics are not hard if you read the book and go to recitation! Recitation clarifies papers and takes participation attendance. GO TO RECITATION!

Genuine guy, you can tell he really enjoys teaching. Lectures aren't mandatory but they really do help to clarify the readings. Same with recitation. Recitation attendance will be used as a tie breaker if you're in between grades at the end of the semester. Plato's Republic was a pretty easy translation to read if you get the new version.
There are only a 5 page midterm and a 5 page final. During the recitation a TA will give the answers to the paper you just have to write it.
Favorite teacher at The Ohio State University. Incredibly friendly, helpful, and approachable. The only class I looked forward to going to, take him at least once for a GE if at all possible.

Going into this class, I had zero interest in or respect for philosophy. Professor Silverman changed that. You can tell he genuinely wants to be there and that he honestly wants to hear what his students think. Take his class--for his stories if nothing else.

Amazing professor. The only class I looked forward to going to. Class covers only Plato's Republic. Silverman does go off on random tangents. Some days we barely covered Plato's Republic. I believe that the tangents were related to the material. Knows everything about OSU. If you need advice on anything OSU related he is the man. Top Notch.

Class was pretty straightforward, only two essays.  He grades the essays pretty harshly, but let us correct them until we got better grades.  Class was fairl interesting, but only focuses on Plato.  Not a very good class for broad intro to philosophy, but good if you like Plato.

Dr. Silverman's lectures are amazing, and he's great at relating to our age group. If you don't read the material, he will chew you out for it. He's really great in office hours, and just wants to see that you're reading and trying to understand the stuff. Dr Silverman does swear profusely in lecture; keep that in mind if you're easily offended
Although class is entertaining and interesting, his teaching style is disorganized and not cogent. It's difficult to distinguish tangents from what you're actually supposed to know.

Very entertaining professor & lots of fun to listen to. A lot to read, but he goes over it in class clearly, so you will be able to pick up all of the main points. Doesn't take attendance every class, only when he feels like it. Doesn't always respond to your emails, which is extremely frustrating. Still, this guy is one of the best at Ohio State.

If you come prepared to class, and have an interest in philosophy Silverman's lectures are enlightening. If you don't like reading, or being called out for sloppy thinking/talking, don't take it.  Also, he will be more than happy to help you in office hours.

Silverman is a great prof if you are looking for a lecturer who will keep you entertained and make you want to go to class. Unfortunately, he does have a tendency to wander from tangent to tangent. Assuming you read and understand all of the material, you should be fine, as all of the papers are essentially just regurgitating arguments.

Dr. Silverman was good-natured and pretty funny, but the class was unorganized and sometimes it was hard to keep track of what we were expected to know versus what was just an aside. The TA's created the grading rubric for both the midterm essays and the final essay, so ask them about it first.

This guy is pretty hilarious.  He doesn't always explain things in a linear, clear-cut way, but in the end, everything comes over.  And the only assignments for 301 are 2 short midterm papers and a longer final paper.

If you want funny stories with 9 gasp - curse words, then Prof. Silverman is the man for you. If you'd like cogent, non-tangential class discussions that don't make you wish you'd stayed home and re-read the material instead, then stay away. Certainly not all he's cracked up to be, I'm afraid.

I took him for 301 and 601. He won't just give you answers or have you memorize facts...he really wants you to learn. He is really smart and knows so much about what he is teaching. Some people (who aren't interested in really thinking through philosophy) won't like him but if you enjoy philosophical discussions he is a great teacher!!!
He is really funny
Teaching style, though entertaining, is uncogent and muzzy.
No Comments
this guy is not helpful even in his office hours.  his criticisms on papers are random question marks.  he had us buy HIS book ($$$) and did NOT use it in his course.
No Comments

Silverman is an excellent Professor by Ohio State standards. I love philosophy, but my ability to give any one thing more than 40 minutes of my attention is rather low, but he can keep you interested with discussion rather than just lecture. This combined with his wit will keep you awake and attentitive. If you dislike talking in class--don't take him; take a class in public speech.

I had Allan for three (!) courses while at OSU -- he was also my major advisor -- I love this guy.  Can ramble a bit and be off the wall, but genuinely nice (we've stayed in touch and he's always been available to talk/give advice/point me to contacts).

Silverman is clearly brilliant and engaged with the material, but he has no pedagogical ability whatsoever.  His lectures are rambling and unhelpful in tackling difficult text.  His lectures demonstrate no discernible forethought or structure.  Much of led discussion is tangential to relevant text.

Pretty good class and a great professor. He takes the time to explain whatever u have questions about and his explanations are good. His lectures can be both hilarious and off the wall but there are those occasional days where its pretty boring. Its great u get a chance to rewrite papers too.

Sometimes its hard to take notes since the lectures can be somewhat unstructured, but he's engaging and sometimes pretty funny.  Also lets you rewrite papers as many times as you want, which is a great way to teach a philosophy course.

He is absolutely amazing!!!  I love this guy so much.  I want to take more classes of his.  If I didn't have his class I would go listen on my own time to him speak.  Just a great PROF... Everyone should take this class.... He's hilarious too....  "Some people are just ****ing crazy." -Silverman..:)
crazy guy, good sense of humor, but very abstract on everything.  be sure to read since he calls on people randomly in lecture

I liked his class.  He either pissed me off or left me with a smile everyday.  He brings philosophy to our generation through Plato's Republic.  I particularly liked when he touched on modern music/art like eminem.  I have recommended this professor to several friends of mine.
No problem staying interested in his lectures. Entertaining. Highly recommend.

Entertaining. Great lectures. Normally hate any lecture, and as senior,this is the ONLY class I have enjoyed. He is into the topic, and makes student involvement fun. Down to earth, and helpful to students. Come to class, write one paper, easy "A,&qu
Absolutley the best teacher that I have ever had. Read the material and go to class and you will get A. He makes you think for yourself, and pushes you to expand your horizons. Great Prof
absolutely outstanding prof. take a class with him!

It's true that he's insane, and judging by his teaching methods, he likely thinks himself to be the reincarnation of Socrates. But this class was one of the most intellectually stimulating that I've taken.  Highly recommended.
Very good prof. cool guy too, very entertaining.  If you can read and write well, you'll do fine.
great speaker, entertaining, but teaches a class that is of a freshmen majority and of a topic that finds many students wondering why they selected the course because of the complex ideas suggested

It's bad enough for a professor to focus on only ONE philosophical work throughout a course, but as a fan of Philosophy, I can say that I'm extremely disappointed to see that that one work is Plato's "Republic."  Tedious, uninspired, and shamefu
No Comments
Great teacher and very interested in helping students learn.  One of the few intructors left who actually holds people accountable for their work.
No Comments
If you can write a good essay, and you can read complicated material, you will do well in his courses.
take this class
Doesn't give much work.  Must pay attention and go to class to do well.  He is sometimes unclear and deals in way too many abstractions.
Doesn't give much work.  Must pay attention and go to class to do well.  He is sometimes unclear and deals in way too many abstractions.
No Comments
Horrible teacher and egomaniac.  Not even sure of his sanity
never should  teach  again
good teacher, not for the feeble minded
worst  prof  ever, horrible person
No Comments

Prof Harmon was a really good dude and his lectures were pretty engaging. The whole class was just 2 papers but he was an easy grader. If you reach out he will always help you out. He is very knowledgeable in philosophy and brings up so many arguments from different viewpoints. Readings aren't very necessary.
Great professor, great lecturer and overall nice guy. I have taken 2 classes with him so far.

Harmon is incredible at simplifying complex concepts for students. Lectures aren't mandatory, but very helpful. If you attend all the lectures, you really don't have to do the readings, as the lectures essentially just overview the important parts of the reading. Very few grades, which is tough, but he is clear in what he expects for assignments.

This class consisted of 2 papers and 1 midterm. The lectures were not too boring and Prof Harmon was able to give clear examples of each concept. He was also easily reachable and clear on what he expected for each paper and midterm.

Even though this was a lecture heavy class, the 55 minutes never seemed to drag on. Content covered and the rubrics for papers were clearly stated. Honestly, if you just show up and listen, writing the papers and taking the midterm are not too difficult.

Good but occasionally repetitive lectures. He does a great job engaging students. If possible, take a class where you can watch the lectures online instead of actually attending. He talks slow enough that you can put it on 2x speed and still understand perfectly. Grading was dependent on the TA for this class, but lectures were comprehensive.
Harmon is a fun professor that knows how to simplify complicated ideas. Great lectures with clear slides for note-taking. Recitations were helpful for questions and discussions.

Professor Harmon was a really nice guy. The lectures were okay, I zoned out a lot though. I think as long as you pay attention and do the readings you'll be fine. I think the main reason I didn't get the best grade is that I had trouble concentrating and sometimes skimmed the readings.

fritz is a super cool guy, kinda strict but you can tell that he loves what he does. His lectures were kinda boring but he kept us interactive with each other. during the switch to online after spring break he was super nice and accomodating with grades. his class did get harder and required more work after the switch to online but its manageable.

Jamie is a great professor who is very relatable. There were a few papers and small reading assignments but other than that it was a fun class. I took it when there were a few bad snow storms so my grade was affected by the required attendance unfortunately.

If you like philosophy and would like to put a bunch of time into it, then he might be your best choice. His class is time-consuming, and grading is extremely strict. He doesn't provide a clear outline of the concepts, you have to pick up every concept from the reading materials. His explanation is not clear, no notes - exam impossible Avoid him.

Small amount of reading required for daily quizzes. Exams were significantly harder than quizzes, but 2-3 hours of flash card work should put you in the A range. Material was a bit dry up until the last third of the class. Professor Smart is a good lecturer and easy to talk to outside of class.

Great guy, but class shouldn't be this difficult as an engineering gen ed. We have other classes to worry about. Quizzes on the readings before teaching the concepts in class, which I did poorly on. Exams weren't terrible but he grades hard. TAKE NOTES IN CLASS. No class curve because there are curves to each exam. But, he truly cares for students.

Dr. Smart cant teach to save his life. His lectures are long and boring, his exams are unnecessarily difficult because of the vague and tricky questions he asks not to mention the tough grading. He also has a no screen policy that is HEAVILY enforced. If you can, avoid him at all costs.
Good luck on the midterms.

His lectures are a bit hard to follow as he would go off-topic sometimes. However, if you see him during office hours and ask him the right questions, he can make things very clear. The first exam was difficult because the wording was weird but he adjusted it for the second exam. Overall, he knows his stuff so he's not as bad as people say.
This guy is trash thats all i have to say. Class is needlessly hard, he is a terrible teacher. He takes his job way too serious.

Everyday feels like its his first day teaching. His lectures are easy to understand and he goes over the material if you ask him, but there is no questions to be ask because the material is easy. When it comes to the exams, he makes the exams extremely hard for no reason.

He is not a bad professor by any means and he is willing to go the extra mile for students and has fun lectures - that being said, he grades very hard for no reason on the exams. The questions are vague and confusing ... very tricky. If you pay attention and kind of try you'll get a B, but if you want an A you will have to work very hard.
Hes a super hard grader on exams and his lectures are hard to follow because theyre all over the pace. He abbreviates everything he writes on the board so its hard taking notes.
I don't know why he makes questions the way he does, you can literally debate with him your answer. He allows that! That's all I have to say.

He is such a boring professor and the exams are very hard. He makes lectures over material that take at most 1 hour of readings last 4-5 lectures, while barely even evaluating the material even more. The classroom was super hot so it was not helpful when trying to learn in class (not his fault). I would recommend staying away from him at all cost

Decent amount of reading, but if you take notes using his study guides the quizzes are pretty easy. Exams are kind of difficult for a GE, but you have a pretty good idea of what he's going to ask if you go to class. While he isn't the best at communicating it, Dr. Smart does care for his students and does seem to know a lot about philosophy/ethics.
Worst prof ever! All that effort and got an E.

His lectures aren't clear, his test questions are vague sometimes. Hardest GE I've taken so far. His teaching method isn't developed, but he has good intentions. He's very dedicated in philosophy but not the best at communicating.
The concepts weren't explained very well in class, but he had office hours during finals to clarify concepts. I hope he gets better with presenting material in his future classes.

Exams were difficult, oftentimes I was baffled as to how I did poorly. Quizzes are 50% individual and 50% group, which made them doable. He is genuinely interested in what he is teaching and is willing to help students when they need help, but the class is graded pretty hard for a Gen-Ed 1000 level course.

Dr. Smart can keep talking on and on, the wording of his exams are often unclear, and overall, it is a little too difficult to get an A for a GE. That being said, he is accessible outside of class and does create some helpful group activities to reinforce concepts.
heavy dry reading.

Had lots of fun in this class despite initially being really interested in the subject matter as it was a GE course. Its critical that you understand the material from the beginning or else you will fall behind, but Aaron does a fantastic job teaching it. He allowed corrections on the first exam and curved the second and final, which was helpful!

Solid professor. Exams are not too challenging. If you read, youll keep up well. There is homework every night, not too challenging. Prof is not understanding/forgiving, but he is funny and interesting. Lectures arent boring. Did not curve final or overall grade. Curved midterm due to technical difficulties, allowed test corrections for 1st exam.

PHILOS 1332 - Engineering Ethics by Lucas Dunlap, is a solid class to take to fulfill the ethics GE for engineers. Dr. Dunlap is very knowledgeable with ethical/moral theories and a good section of the class is dedicated to understanding some of these common moral theories. 4 writing assignments 2 midterms 1 final paper Show up to class, get an A

He's really thorough and passionate about the subject, but his explanations of things are a little hard to unpack. Definitely go to class even if you read the book because the book is heavy so having him reinforce what you read is definitely helpful. The only annoying thing about him is if you miss class, he will make you feel bad about it

Funny guy, super interested in what he was teaching. Easy grader, but still gave really genuine feedback on essays or tests. Definitely make sure to read the book, because honestly if you do, you probably don't need to go to class. Do the readings or pay attention in class, listen to his feedback, and you have an easy A

This class was great!! Alex was so passionate about what he was teaching; he used a lot of tough language that was a little hard to grasp, but that goes with any philosophy class. There are no exams, just papers and presentations. Submit rough drafts!! He is so helpful and willing to give feedback. My grade was nearly 100%. Attendance is taken.

There is a lot of reading, so be prepared for that! He goes by Alex and is super laid back and genuine...a wonderful human. Philosophy was hard for me to grasp, but he explains things in different ways until you get it! You cannot miss more than 2 or 3 classes or your grade is deducted, just an fyi! I would take another class from him anytime!

All he is looking for in you is participation. If you show up and do the things in class, then you will pass. You have to sign up for a discussion in the semesterm, and you read the pages for that day and bring up a discussion in class. Little nerve-wracking, but easy. The final is an essay. I am not the best student and it was an easy A!

Less than 10 assignments all semester, all papers. No exams. This class is all about reading and talking about what you read, you don't have to attend every class but it is suggested because he thoroughly goes through each reading which helps for papers. It can be boring but he is a good guy.
Despite being from Greece, he speaks clearly and you can barely tell any accent. He is kind and fair. The readings you dont really need to do to follow along with the class discussion.
Great at giving feedback on papers. Was a little intimidating in class, but you'll get used to her quickly and then everything will be fine.

Class is easy, just reading daily and then class discussions. Is a fine instructor and all until papers roll around and no one get a 100%... class averages on papers is 85% usually which majorly tanks grade in the class bringing down gpa. Fritz grades way too harsh and his rubric for papers is super vague. wouldnt recommend

I have never rated a professor before, but I felt the need to strongly encourage other students to take a class with Dr. Habash. He is phenomenal and by far the best professor I have ever had at Ohio State. Interesting course material and he is passionate, kind, funny, and also easy on the eyes. Cares about students and teaches in an engaging way!

Way too harsh a grader. Seems like a smart man. Would be 100x better if he could communicate the material and involve his students. I love my first Philos course but hated his due to his pedantic lecture style. Would not take again.

Found out through this course Philosophy is just not for me. If you never skip lecture, you barely have to read (me). Some things were not very clear, but discussing what makes up our morals is not clear. My only complaint is his responses to students' questions were long winded, made it hard for other students' comment.

Definitely an interesting class, but be ready for many periods with straight lecture for the entire duration.  No tests, just several papers.  Getting an A is in your power if you read, and write thoroughly.

The hardest intro class I have ever taken. I had a passing interest in philosophy and he crushed it with his pedantic lectures and completely insane and arbitray grading. Going to office hours was not helpful, half the time he was late or didn't show up. He failed to answer any of my questions about the course material in a straightforward maner.

I absolutely hated Symbolic Logic. It was awful. But, Taschek is a great professor, and I would definitely have taken another class from him - as long as it was not a logic class. Definitely one of the better professors in the department to take this class from. Attendance isn't mandatory, but you should show up. There is some extra credit given.
Confusing and it's not just philosophy.
He's ok. Knowledgeable and helpful, but tends to ramble on for the entire two hour class, which gets boring. I think this is probably typical of any philosophy professor though...

Yes, Dr. Taschek is a hard grader. But, if you really really put time into the papers, you WILL get an A. Go to class, it helps. They key is just really giving your papers some thought and visiting him with any questions you have before you turn in your papers.
Okay, so he's hard.  And his comments on papers can seem harsh.  But in my case they hit the mark,and I could do better next time.

Understood the material well, but since this subject is vague and hard to understand, the class was kind of vague and hard to understand. If you go to his office hours, he'll help you understand a little better and he'll definately help you with your paper.
Taschek is a very smart man who communicates the subject matter well.  Take his class if you want to learn, but the class was pack with too much information and assignments for me.

He's a very good lecturer, and knows the subject extremely well.  Yes, he gives harsh comments, but this is a GOOD thing, since they will only improve your writing, and the actual grading is fair.  My only complaints are that there was a ton of reading, and at times he moved a bit too quickly in lecture, but overall I enjoyed the class quite a bit.
Very articulate/ well spoken
Brilliant man.  Classes were boring though as he just talked for the whole hour and forty-eight minutes.  Very excited to teach but harsh on the grading.

Taschek is very intelligent and ectremely knowledgeable in his field, but perhaps is overly qualified to be teaching an introduction level course. No midterm and a take home final were major perks. A hard grader on the papers though.

Professor Taschek was very difficult. He was a very hard grader and had extremely harsh comments over the papers. Although there wasn't a lot of work, there was a lot of reading and the papers were difficult. His lectures were boring and uninvolved. It was hell just trying to stay awake. I now have no interest in philosophy at all.

Worst professor I have ever had. Basically threatened students to participate in class. Very hard grader. Showed up to every class and still learned absolutely nothing. If anything, my perception on philosophy is more confusing and worse than it has ever been. TAKE A DIFFERENT SECOND LEVEL WRITING COURSE.

Professor Weiss is a fantastic professor and really has a passion for teaching philosophy/ethics. You are really pushed to think in every class and it's pretty fascinating stuff. Biggest critique is lack of feedback on essays/presentation grading, but I understand because he had a rough semester in his personal life (health).

Prof. Weiss was great. Cared a lot about the subject matter, but wasn't a tough grader and understood that most people are only taking the class because it's a gen ed. Only had 1 essay, and the exams weren't too hard (if you review lecture notes). The final project is a group presentation, which wasn't too hard.

I loved taking his engineering ethics class there was three papers that amounted to 90% of your grade and 10% was just coming to class and participating by having something to say. He really challenges you to think about the ethics of multiple different situations and things. One of my more favorite professors I've had in the three years of school.

Pretty easy A if you do the work. You also learn a significant amount from this class. He is very flexible, several students, including me, were allowed extensions on our final paper because we didn't format it correctly despite him saying that he would never do that. He wants you to learn and be inspired by the material.

I really liked Jeremy. Even though his grading might seem difficult, he was very very helpful in office hours and I would recommend seeing him. He is a very fair grader, and although assignments can be a lot of work, he does not grade excessively harshly like some people in the philosophy department. He is also very knowledgeable and intelligent.

He reeks of cigarettes. In a small classroom, it's gag-inducing. He's a cool guy in one sense, but also kind of self-important. Uses huge words in regular conversation to an obnoxious level. We get it, you're intellectual. More reading than possible, esp for busy ENGR majors. Participate in class discussion.

Class material was engaging. Very helpful during office hours and extremely understanding. I was actually allowed to retake a quiz (albeit in person) when I said that my internet crapped out and left half of my answers blank. Caring professor and would certainly take his class again any day. I picked up a philosophy minor because of him.

Participation is expected which includes going to office hours. Very strict on grading midterms (mean midterm 1 score is low 70). He assigns two online quizzes a week over the reading and expect to read at least 30+ pages a week. His lectures are super boring and majority of the class eventually stops listening.

He does a great job getting engineering students interested in philosophy. The essays are pretty hard but going to office hours really helps. He has high expectations for a gen ed, but putting some effort into essays and following the lectures will get you a good grade. He's really engaging and interesting, and I'm glad I took his class.

His class is fantastic. He does a phenomenal job getting you into philosophy and making the material interesting. Additionally, he has an amazing beard that he strokes whenever he posits a philosophically challenging question. He is everything you could ever hope for in a professor for philosophy.

Professor Weiss lectures over interesting and engaging subjects, but he has extremely high expectations, especially considering most students take his class as a simple GE. He forewarns students within the first week that they should not expect to get an A and grades papers and quizzes very harshly.

Not a good class for those who take it as General course. Lots of papers, not helpful at the office hours, wasting your time for stupid papers, tough grader! He does everything to prove that he's teaching the most important course in OSU!

If you go to his class, do the readings, and spend some time writing your papers you will do fine. He provides all of the text for the class so no book is needed. He almost gives you the answers to the midterm if you go to his review session. Also, he offers extra credit - I would advise you take advantage.

Expects you to heavily participate. Grades very harshly for things as simple as a group quiz. Graded the midterm harshly (Medium 79%). Lots of reading every class (some over 20 pages!!!!). If you're interested in philosophy I'd recommend him, but for someone just looking for an easy gen ed, AVOID!!

Dr. Jeremy Weiss is an excellent, passionate professor who encourages thoughtful discussion about the class' important material on ethics. While he may grade harder than others, he is fair, and I found that to be motivating; we should not expect an easy A for non-major classes. I highly recommend him for students actually interested in thinking.

Jeremy is terrific. He really cares about all of his students. He facilitates engaging discussions in class, as long as you are willing to participate. The downside is that even if you complete every assignment and don't skip, he grades quizzes and papers as though it were 2000-3000 level. Despite this, he's a great dude and highly recommend him.

He is truly very interesting and has solid class discussions but he assigns almost no graded assignments.  This would be fine but the ones he grades he thrashes.  He believes he is grading a 4000 major class but its just checking off a gen ed for most. Dont take this guy.  oh and he takes participation grades super serious so you must speak up

This guy is a good teacher but is an incredible hard grader I had a 4.0 before his class and I got a B in his class. Would not recommend. Also, he isn't helpful in office hours he just stares with a blank face

Cool guy. Really enjoyed his class even though he gave me a lower grade than I think  I earned. Very interesting and not very hard, though there are very few grades so any bad grade hurts you a lot. It's not hard to avoid the bad grades though.  Not usually necessary to be in class; great discussions, but not in terms of learning for the class.

Honestly, his class discussions were very interesting. But he assigns 3 papers which are 7-8 pages long. Difficult questions to attempt. Grades them like you are presenting a research paper. It should be a 5000 level class not 1000 level. There are other professors out there who just takes 3 multiple choice exams. Avoid him and take other class!
Steven takes so long to grade anything
The WORST professor at OSU. TOUGH grader. His class average on projects is 60%....

DO **NOT** TAKE THIS PROFESSOR. He is a PhD student and grades us like we are PhD students ourselves. This was supposed to be an intro level course but he made it the hardest class I've ever taken for undergrad.

New teacher who doesn't know much. He doesn't know how to answer questions because he can't comprehend what you're saying. He takes attendance using tophat and changes the course password for every class. He doesn't know how to teach and paces around making people get in groups to waste class time. The Midterm took an ENTIRE day to complete.
One of my favorite professors ever. Super understanding but also committed to making sure you understand how to build your reasoning.

Great teacher, highly recommended. You will gets some free point, plus some bonus. Very funny too. I use to not like philosophy, but a great teacher make you want attend class. His lecture is good, test / quiz are all right, as soon as you do a little reading, you be fine
He's pretty much hilarious.  Plus, he's a good teacher and a good guy.

Matt is a wonderful professor! He is funny and entertaining while still paying attention to the course material.  He let the class talk as much as we wanted about the issues but did not pressure us into class participation.  Great class!

I have taken two classes with Matt now. He is wonderful. He really enjoys teaching. Sometimes lecture/discussion is boring, but it is always worth going to class. And Matt Jordan deserves 5 Chili Peppers!!!
matt is awsome. This class was not very much fun though.  Lots of reading and papers.  No midterms or tests though.  Kind of hard to understand for a 1st philo class

Matt Jordan. Where to begin. He loves teaching and is very understandable to student's needs. He is pretty clear in his lectures and truly makes the classroom a fun place to be. Not too much work required, although I think he is a tough grader. Matt is funny and made the class fun. So kudos to you Matt, here are some chili peppers.

Everyone in my class loved this instructor. His philosophy of religion class was awesome. He is probably the funniest instructor I've ever had, and extremely kind too. In class we read essays rather than a textbook. Grades consist of 5 2 page papers, a term paper, a journal, and a few pop quizzes. It sounds like a lot, but the class is worth it.
Down to earth guy, humorous at times
What can I say, Matt is Bomb shell and a fantabulous teacher.

Matt Jordan is AWESOME! So funny! I actually liked attending class. The readings were a bit daunting, but if you fill out the study questions along with the reading, you are guaranteed to get good grades on the quizzes! Attendance not mandatory, but he does give pop quizzes and he let's you use study questions! I highly recommend Matt!
clear and fun teacher

Matt is probably the funniest instructor ever. He's also very nice and laid back. Attendance is optional but there were pop quizzes every few class periods, so it's worth it to show up. The class consisted of 5 short papers (2-3pg), 4 journal entries, and a term paper (5-7pg). There were no exams. I HIGHLY recommend Matt. Best instructor ever.

extremely funny, makes the material extremely interesting. in a class that would be easy to offend, he's extremely nice and understanding. definitely take this class, it's a good change of pace and he's very helpful. oh and i never bought the book and still got an A.

Good professor. Effective in explaining the material, and remember to ask questions if you don't get it. He has a great sense of humor, and can relate to students well. The discussions on ethical situations were pretty good, too. Worst part about my class was the students. They didn't seem interested, and weren't shy about saying so. Very nice guy

Matt has a great sense of humor and i always leave his class with a smile...he tries to make class fun and relate it to us but his exams are a little tricky and he is a very strict grader...otherwise he makes ethics enjoyable

Very helpful and clear in explaination. It's too bad that he couldn't have taught the class instead of Makoto Suzuki. It sucked that there were only lectures taught by Suzuki and no recitations, leaving Matt very few chances to clarify his explainations. However, he helped in the best way that he could by setting Makoto straight.
He looks like a lumberjack.  He had a baby at the end of the quarter.  AWWW.  I'm giving him his first review:-)

Shapiro is SO BORING! He reteaches the same things over and over again, so it feels like the course never progresses. He often makes mistakes and, when corrected, blames his old age. It is almost impossible to make myself attend lecture because the TA teaches exactly what you need to know for the quizzes anyway in recitation.

Nice guy, but he's seriously the worst professor I've had. The TA should've taught the class. If you can learn from 20-minute tangents and a guy who says, "I'll probably do this wrong, but [the TA] will correct me, knock yourself out. Otherwise, avoid this class.
If you're trying to get your GEC's out of the way, take this class. Lectures are a little boring, but the class is extremely easy. No sweat. Take it if you can.

Great professor!  There were 3 700 word essays, 3 group discussions (easy) and a final (essay).  Overall not a bad class.  He explains things very well and constantly reminds you when assignments are due, which is really nice.  Make sure to take good notes because the final is open note!  I would recommend this class :)
At first, I thought this class was horrible, but, as the quarter goes by, it grows on you. If you're willing to do the work and back up your opinions, then you'll earn his respect.

He's a pretty good professor that likes to throw in his own brand of humor periodically to keep people awake. The class can be pretty dry, but if you copy down every example on the board, review them, and do the homework you will most likely get a good grade.  Exam problems are much easier than a lot of the homework problems.Don't ever skip class.
hes really understanding, if you dont quite get something hes always willing to help, and he takes into account your participation and how much you show up to class.
hes an all aroudn great guy.

Material covered in lectured is very fast.  Sometimes his lectures were highly confusing. I took this instead of math... from what I hear I would reccommend taking 150 instead- it seems much easier. very helpful, yet all over the place.  You really have to focus in this class and do the homework for a decent grade.

Prof. Shapiro rarely ever stayed on topic. I found his class really hard to pay attention in, because it seemed like most of what he was saying was totally pointless. He didn't do any grading in this class, the TA did, and the TA did a way better job teaching than Shapiro did.

Extremely scatterbrained. He knows what he's talking about, but just assumes you do too. I was so lost and felt like if I asked him to explain it he'd just make me feel slow. Other than that, he's a nice guy.
Fantastic professor. Clear, good teacher with an interest in teaching and in his students. Quite a fun class. Highly recommended.

Shapiro is a very boring instructor and he tends to ramble. His grading is all over the place and his comments are confusing and hard to read. However, he lets you rewrite your essays, so it's not a big deal. It's a pretty easy class, so if you don't mind being bored for two hours, then I would recommend him.
Pretty good teacher.  He's pretty funny when he lectures--kind of eccentric.  It's true that he makes the TA's do a lot of the work, but the class was really easy.

This class was very pointless, and Dr. Shapiro did not do a good job teaching it.  The material was inherently easy, but he made it much more confusing than it needed to be.  He rambled, he messed up his math constantly, he didn't explain anything well, and he completely relied on his TAs.  I do not recommend taking a class from him.
He was all right. Tended to ramble on about things that no one really cared about, but some of his stories were entertaining. Quizzes were frequent but easy.
sucks @ grading papers. horrible comments. not clear in his lectures.
he is a very nice guy, very helpful, full of good explinations and suggestions, VERY funny, good material.
Very opinionated and stubborn.  Horrible grader with horrible comments, and horrible lectures.  He's an okay person if you don't mind being bored or getting Bs.
Very opinionated and not very helpful.  Especially disorganized and a more subjective, rather than objective grader.
definitely an easy class. definitely looks like richard dreyfuss. the work gets boring, and so do the lectures. but fufills a gec and im pretty sure is the easiest choice for doing so.

Shapiro is a quirky and fun lecturer, unfortunately the material leaves something to be desired. The course is not very difficult. I recommend it if you just want to get your data analysis GEC taken care of; the class requires little effort.
Good class, very nice teacher
Repeats himself a lot, and his voice sounds strangely like Richard Dreyfus's.  I had this class early in the morning, so I skipped a lot, but he seemed to be a pretty good professor.

i've taken 3 courses with him. a really nice teacher although sometimes confusing and unclear. he's always there to clarify and allows students to rewrite papers. he definately takes effort into consideration when assigning grades

He is a little crazy..but a nice man.  Will cut a little slack if your smart and you actually do your work.  Just had to write papers, and he let us re-write them.  But that was summer quarter, no promises.

From day one, no clear syllabus was given and the entire class was poorly organized. Grades are given based on how he feels and not supported with a rubric, grading scale, etc. Most lectures are not pre-planned. Do not let the 1500-level label fool you. This class can be a GPA-wrecker due to his lack of structure and impossible grading standards.
Overall, the class was unorganized. Giorgio is a tough grader on exams and fails to clarify many topics that became confusing throughout the class.

Giorgio is a cool person, but a very poor instructor. He was terrible at clarifying concepts in class and graded harshly on the homework. There was never a time a question was asked and he actually answered it. He failed to give sufficient feedback on homework and exams. His standards for grading are very unclear.
He is beautiful

Giorgio is an excellent teacher, he really made up for the poor job the professor did for the class. He's very friendly and is happy to help.  He's also just a laid back guy in general, loves to crack jokes or get a bit carried away with conversations about soccer. Would definitely recommend.
Giorgio is nice, comprehensive, and can actually teach...unlike the professor for the class. Also, he is gorgeous. Just saying.

Dr. Lavender McKittrick-Sweitzer is a gem. Her class was deeply relevant, but was pretty dense on the reading side. Some readings take 2+ hours to read through but that reading and subsequent discussions deeply refine ones critical reading/writing/thinking skills. She was very very kind. I think this class should be required for everyone.

I learned nothing from his class 3410, which was easier than any 1000 level philosophy class.
