There was at least one group discussion per class, and the topics were so stupid, people finish it in 5 minutes, but he gave more than 10 minutes. If you do not chat with others, then it would be count as a low participation grade (17% of your final grade

Heavy reading but he posts summaries online post-lecture, so don't HAVE to do them. Exam is a few in-class essays, but topics given a week in advance to study. A few very long papers but directions are detailed enough to make them a breeze. A few reading responses, only a couple pages. Never touched textbook and got an A.

Professor Katz is such a nice guy and really cares about his students. There is quite a bit of reading and a lot of content, but the class isnt too stressful. I tend to look forward to doing to assignments and like to prepare because I respect him as a teacher. I learned so much and enjoyed doing it

Professor Katz is a really good instructor! He is very open minded and very intelligent in his responses and doesn't make you feel dumb in the process. Be ready to read because if you don't do the readings, you'll be lost during class.
Corey Katz is a passionate professor and I enjoy going to his class everyday! The assignments although often are clearly outlined & fairly graded. Would totally reccommend him to a friend!

Corey is passionate about ethics and it shows in his teaching. He tries to engage everyone in class discussions and to help you think critically about your own values using ethical theories. Course was reading and writing heavy (weekly readings, 4 papers), but he graded fairly. Take his class if you are interested in applied ethics!

The class started out simple but pretty soon became a parade of increasingly complex stuff from Descartes to A.J. Ayer to W.V. Quine(!) to Saul Kripke to Frank Jackson; and we ended with feminist critical theory. Not at all what I was expecting for 3000, but absolutely worth it if you put in the effort. 3 graded papers, mandatory attendance.

Tristram is pretty awesome. The class is tough, but if you apply yourself you will get a lot out of it. His lectures really helped me learn the material and I feel like a much more conscious writer now. Funny too
One of the hardest classes I have ever taken. Him nor his TA are willing to give good feedback when it comes to the two major papers. Very heavy in reading. Would never recommend taking this class.

Professor McPherson's class was very lecture heavy. There wasn't much class work (2 papers, 5 small assignments, and weekly discussion posts only about 150 words), but attending class was so boring. Attendance wasn't "required" but you got points for writing notes not the assigned readings and you couldn't pass the class without them.

Professor McPherson's ethics class is graded on two papers, a final, and participation points. A reading is required before every lecture, usually about 8-10 pages. His lectures are reasonably engaging and interesting, especially if you are already interested in ethics.

Tristram's super upfront about everything you have to in order get a decent grade. He seems to give more HW than the typical philosophy class, but they help you engage w/ the readings and cushion your overall grade. The readings are fairly difficult, but if you attend the classes, he does a great job at explaining incredibly difficult concepts.

There is a lot of homework in this class, worth points, but most of it is graded on completion. There were also two papers and a final. The two papers were graded very harshly and based on professors opinions. He ended up curving the final because the grades were so low. I would not recommend taking this class if you are looking for an easy GE.

In Professor Shuster' class I felt safe to share. All opinions are welcomed and supported. Grades are generally based on completion of routine tasks. A knowledgeable philosopher with a really sweet personality.

Dr. Shuster is very sweet. Many people in my class were confused but I think GE courses are always a little hard to follow because of the broad spectrum of content while keeping them 'introductory.' I would easily take a class with Amy again, they are extremely kind and good at giving you feedback on work/answering emails.

Prof Shuster's course is very untraditional, but she tries hard to engage all students and ensure everyone is contributing to the group learning process.  She's supportive of students and clearly outlines her expectations for coursework.  Coursework isn't harshly graded, but there is a lot of reading, and preparation is necessary in class!

Professor Shuster has so many great qualities, but they have a bit of a 'god complex' in that they believe they are always right which so many students in my class found so frustrating.They would also just say out of pocket stuff sometimes & it would throw everybody off. But overall a cool professor who just wants to make the world a better place.

She is very knowledgeable about this material, but fails to realize students don't grasp the concepts like she does. This is also a lower level philosophy course, yet she uses other philosophers and concepts to explain the material we are reading. Students don't understand her similes and references because we haven't studied philosophy like her.

Lectures are interesting, and she does her best to get everyone to speak up. She gives feedback and sometimes allows revisions on assignments. The class is not very well organized though, and assignments seem to be graded more on writing style than how you relate with the material. Also, be prepared to get emails every day.

This is by far the most painful class I've endured. The material is not hard but the lectures are incredibly boring and confused. Rather than engaging with the whole class shuster answers questions from students as if the other students are not there. the class should be easy but the incredibly boring atmosphere makes it near impossible to attend

One of the best professors I've had. Lecture's were engaging and we always had something cool to talk about during class. The gateway seminar is renowned for being a weed-out class, but not with Dr. Willis, he's the goat. The entire class is 3 papers and so long as you follow the rubric you'll get an easy A. He also gives amazing feedback. 10/10
Intro to Rational Choice was super interesting and a class I think everyone should take. It is clear Professor Willis cares deeply about the topic and makes learning accessible for everyone.

I found the lectures engaging (mostly discussion based). Matt is empathetic and encouraging, makes me feel like I can do philosophy. He can quickly grasp what people were trying to say and paraphrase it in elegant ways. He would assign readings on the same issue written by different sides. About 20 pages of reading due before every class.
He made class very interesting and kept me involved, and was willing to be flexible with grading late assignments as long as you reach out to him

He is very chill. Exams were super easy. He allowed us to email him our answers for him to check before we actually turned them in. There is a "random" weekly writing assignment, but they are mostly on Fridays.

Professor Willis was very good at encouraging discussion and had interesting lectures that I attended regularly. I was sick one week and he let me make up one of the in-class writing assignments via email, so he is pretty chill about things as long as you get them in. He is also a pretty easy grader for exams.

Matthew was a good lecturer and easy grader as long as you put the minimum amount of effort in. He made engineering ethics more enjoyable than I expected, and made sure the class was a GPA boost. Only critique was the lectures were way longer than necessary but that's also due to class participation.
Awesome at guiding discussions through content. Gives pretty good feedback on arguments helping to build the mind of a philosopher better.

Matt's class was my favorite this semester. Great lectures and I always looked forward to class discussions. He goes over what's in the readings in class, but I would still do them if you have time. There's only 3 writing assignments but expectations are clear and he's not a hard grader so you should end up with a good grade if you put in the work.
Great lecturer and brought a lot of clarity to all of the readings. All in all, a really interesting and engaging class. I really recommend.
It was just a very enjoyable class, honestly it was surprising to hear it was the first class he's taught. Would definitely recommend his course to anyone thinking about philosophy as a major/minor.

He's extremely condescending and does not foster a good learning environment at all. He immediately shuts down opinions or ideas that students have about his theories and presents his theories as fact, when philosophy is supposed to be an open minded, discussion-based area of study. His TAs are much better at teaching than him.

Tim is a great professor; he's helpful, intelligent and the lectures are usually interesting. You have to show up and give a damn to do well. Attendance isn't mandatory but your life will be way easier if you go.

Tim is a nice guy and the discussions that he leads in class are always interesting. Attendance isn't taken but you should absolutely go to class in order to get the notes and make sense of the topics. His grading was very unclear sometimes and going to his office hours just made me more confused. Regardless, I learned A LOT in this class.
Good, but strict teacher. Some directions unclear, but other than that hes good.

Likes to keep the appearance of being open minded but quickly shuts down dissenting thoughts even if they have a good point.  Strangely inconsistent on grading.  For the first midterm interpreted the prompt broadly and he praised my creativity and for the final paper I did something similar, maybe even less bold, and he gave me a low grade for it.
I think he's trying to hard to be professorial. The fist day of class I found him extremely pretentious, but he got better over time. I think he is an all around good guy.

Tim isn't the best professor ever, but he certainly isn't the worst. He bases 101H entirely on one book, and it can be exhausting to try to remember everything in the book and understand all of it for exams. Paper is a bit rough....start early. Overall a good teacher; he's extremely intelligent, but it's difficult to stay awake during his lectures.

Tim is actually a genius. He's explaining extremely complicated material, which is why it could seem unclear, but he's incredibly patient, not to mention sincerely helpful, and very witty. Always finishes his jokes. If he were arrogant, which he isn't, he would have sincerely earned the right to be. Like Billy Corgan.

Ok look, this guy is not very warm and fuzzy, but saying that Tim does not know what he is talking about would be wrong. He really encourages participation and tries to make sometimes very confusing subject matter relatable. Class had no midterm but weekly quizzes, 3 argument analysis assignments and a take home final exam.

Shocked by positive feedback. Don't take a class with him. He's a mean person and confusing at explaining topics. We only wrote one paper for the whole class for a grade, didn't understand anything. Reading was awful and dense. Overall a terrible experience. He actually yelled at my class for not participating enough. It sucked.

Disastrous. Turned a philosophy in literature class that I was pumped about taking into something he called "moral psychology" (i.e. disorganized ethics). Entire grade came from 15-20 page term paper; no directions whatsoever. If you want to learn something about philosophy and/or literature, better luck in the English department on that one.
Awful class, uninteresting reading, empty discussion in circles and to top all of that off a 20 page paper which is the only grade.felt like my grade was randomly selected out of a hat.
Tim is not very intelligent, continually toots his own horn.

vague grader. not organized at all. not a very good lecturer. some people seemed to think his jokes were funny... that's probably all he has going for him.you do one paper 4 times and the best grade is your grade for the class. the paper is also vague. his grading is vague. his lectures are vague. don't take phl. of mind with him

He's alright. The man knows a lot about a lot of stuff. Things most people wouldn't bother knowing. He's really disorganized and not very clear in presenting theories. I was disappointed in how devoutly he seemed to present badly flawed theories of mind. Didn't really get what I wanted out of the course, but some people liked him.

I am really quite shocked at the positive reviews Tim has gotten on here. There's a consensus among quite a few of us in his philosophy of Mind class that he comes off as arrogant, doesn't make the classroom conducive to learning and discussion, and gave us a sloppy and disorganized essay off of which we must build for our grade. Don't take.
His class was one of the best I have attended. Great Professor. Recommended for your GEC.
Great class. Paper is a pain
Great prof, the course was discussion based 20 page paper at end but otherwise great

Easiest class I have ever taken.  I only went to class for a few weeks, and ended up with an A- in the class.  Your grade is made up of one in-class paper, and two other papers.  Definitely take this class to fill your GEC and get an easy A.

Great class great teacher. Only 3 grades. Midterm, term-paper, take home final. Theres nothing really learned specifically about philosophy but he makes you think and it's pretty interesting. No required attendence, the book is on spark notes, and if you just go to the lectures and grasp the concepts it's a piece of cake. term paper a little rough.

Instead of talking about many issues, we did just two: Aristotle on ethics and Dennett on consciousness (my mind is still spinning from the second).  The ONLY grades were three essays: one in class and two out of class.  Professor Schroeder is a nice, funny, brilliant guy, but he is not incredibly interested in your success as a student.

Erin was a good professor. She let us argue for our grade at the end of the course. However, I felt like she made us do a lot more work compared to other Engineering Ethics classes from this benefit of arguing for our grade at the end of the course which I didn't really need in my workload.
Professor Mercurio is very kind and accessible outside of class. She really shows that she wants to help students learn if they're interested in her class and reward those who put in some effort.

Overall solid! No real deadlines and you don't get real grades in this class instead argue for it at the end! Group work can be tedious but participate and you're fine! My only complaint is that she gives feedback too slowly and assignments build on top of each other so if your on the wrong track for one, your gonna be stuck for the other ones

Very easy class, and you argue for your grade at the end, so if you show up sometimes and do your work youll be fine. Erin is very flexible with deadlines and is very nice during lecture/group work days. Would definitely recommend, especially if you have a difficult schedule.

The class has a lot of group work, so if you dont show up often, you will get points docked, given your group notices. Its very easy and a super enjoyable class. Erin is extremely kind and is nothing like a classic bitter old professor. She understands that we have classes and is very lenient with deadlines and is just kind in general. Good class

Fantastic, always fun, challenging, encouraging, respectful. Really enjoys teaching, learning , people and philosophy. Great during office hours explaining content as long as you need. Very fair. Can anything in class. Very interesting and very applicable to our life.

I loved this course with Erin! She is an amazing teacher and explains the concepts really well. (Great lectures!) There is no way you'll fail if you go to class regularly and do your homework. The exam averages are usually in the 60s-70s for those who don't come to class, but usually in the B range for those who do. She's a very fair grader.
wish I could take another course with her if I'm not graduating
Prof. Rudavsky is fantastic and inspiring. She is one of the few professors in the philosophy department here that seems to even consider continental philosophy, so that's a big plus too.

Dr. Rudavsky was incredibly fascinating, humourous, and kept the class' attention with her enthralling lectures. Her class was amazing and such a pleasure to take. There was a lot of difficult reading, but none of her selections were boring and she took particular care to make sure we understood what exactly the readings were arguing in lectures.
Dr.Rudavsky is an amazing instructor. She keeps the class engaged by telling comical stories, explains everything clearly. I always leave her class with a different perspective on life.

Prof. Rudavsky is a wonderful professor; I've taken several of her classes and consider them all to be highlights of my undergraduate education. She is an engaging lecturer, incredibly smart, and has a great sense of humor. The material covered in this class can really enrich lives, and I like that it draws in students from a variety of majors.

I took her medieval philosophy class bc I saw the good reviews, but this class was actually very hard. She straight up says that she wants people to fail so she can have her perfect bell curve for grading. She's also very set in her beliefs about philosophy and doesn't leave room for others to have different opinions about debatable topics.

I really love Rudavsky as a professor. She's passionate about what she teaches and cares about individual students. Don't be afraid to reach out and talk to her because she's willing to help. The concepts can be quite hard to understand if you miss lectures so make it a goal to try and attend all or most of them. I would love to have her again.

I've had Prof Rudavsky for both Phil in Lit and Existentialism and would absolutely recommend both. She's incredibly nice and the stuff she teaches is unlike anything else you'll get in the philosophy department. Reading list for this class was a bit much, but it's the second time it's ever been offered so it's still a work in progress.

Every class I've taken with Tamar has been amazing. Her board organizational skills really set the par for the rest of humanity. She can relate ideas to her students really well if they bother coming to class and paying attention.
-very passionate about the subject matter. -board work can be erratic at times, but it makes sense  -makes hard concepts easier to understand -is hot
Such a fun and interesting professor. I love her board work!
She was very interesting and nice.
Great class, good thoughts

Tamar is one of my favorite professors at OSU; she's funny, passionate, and makes you work for it through reading and writing a ton. This is a good thing, for if this is your passion and major then it will be incredibly worth it. Being one of the only professors at OSU who teaches continental philosophy, she is a must take for any philosophy major.

Rudavsky makes up for her somewhat lack of clarity and organization by her passion and interest in the material. Plus, she makes you read, think, and work for your grade, which is how you learn to think and read critically and for yourself. Pretty tough, and sometimes things don't always come together quickly, but well worth it in the end.

Awesome Professor. Genuinely cares about the education of her students, gives more than ample extra credit to boost your grade, and is so passionate about the material she is teaching. She is very knowledgeable. She can and will stop and explain things if they are not clear. In a very hard class to comprehend, she makes it easier to understand.

Professor Rudavsky is a great professor. She's unbelievably knowledgeable and seems to want her students to succeed. Her lectures can be confusing at times, so the course may take extra work in order to understand the material fully. Otherwise, she is a very interesting person and I recommend taking her courses.

Rudavsky does a great job showing how the material in the course can be applied to your everyday life.  And relating the social allusions at the time of the writers to current social status quos.  Her reading outlines are helpful but rather unorganized.  Her blackboard notes are unorganized.

I had her for advanced existentialism, and Tamar seems to be in her element teaching this subject. It was a great class, but it's only downfall was the daunting amount of material we tried to cover. You are a great prof though!

Rudavsky rocks!  the class is hard because the material is complex. She's very willing to help all of her students and makes time to meet outside of class.  Do your readings and engage the class and it will be fun.

I love, love, loved having her for this class! Brilliant and absolutely hilarious. yes...she tells a lot of personal narratives. I thought they were relevant, some did not. But either way, she's open to criticism. She's expressed she reads the comments on this website...HEY Dr. Rudavsky!!! Hope you're doing awesome!

Awesome prof. Interesting material, very animated while teaching, tells great stories. keeps you on your toes without being too overwhelming. coming from a non-philosophy major, definitely take her if you can!

I took her for 301 and then again for 306 because she was so great the first time. I learned a lot from her and loved it. Wonderful professor. She might be intimidating by jumping around, but if you do the readings you don't need to know extra stuff about philosophy to get an A.

Mrs. Rudavsky is a bit off the cuff sometimes. However, I do find her notes (though disorganized) to be quite helpful. She posts a lot of the notes online. Its an absolute must to read them before class. The class consisted of 1 midterm, 1 Final, a 5-7 page paper and 2 quizzes. Very easy if you come to class and pay attention.
Too disorganized.  I survived because I'm a philosophy major.  Most people were lost when studying for midterms.
The class sometimes was brilliant. Other days, not so great. She's a wonderful prof...but like most GEC's the class is graded by a TA. Just hope you have a nice one.
Class was fairly interesting...mine was easy but the TA did all the grading and he was SUPER easy.  She is really unorganized and changes what we were doing all the time, but she's fun to listen to.
She's very interesting...She jumps around a lot and is very enthusiastic and passionate. Take Philosophy 306 with her. Highly recomended!
Great professor, she made an uninteresting subject bearable!

She's knowledgeble and the material is very interesting. My only problem with her was that she was very disorganized, both w/r/t lectures and  assignments. She changed due dates for papers, forgot to post topics, and changed the requirements a lot, so it was hard to keep track of what we needed to do. Even so, I enjoyed the class quite a bit.
One of the best philosophy professors I've had.  Class was challenging and interesting.

As far as presentation, she is energetic and intersted.  As for clarity, her writing is everywhere and her personal stories, entertaining as they are, take up more class time than aristotle.  Would recommend taking someone else.
Super smart and funny. She tells the craziest stories!
very fun, makes you want to go to class.

You can tell she actually cares about what she's talking about and she's funny as sh*t. I feel like I learned a lot in her class and enjoyed myself while doing it. I'll never forget about her "perfect lover" (take her class and you'll understand).

I had her for philos 270, 302, and 602. She is the smartest woman i have every met. Her personality will make you interested in anything that she is teaching. She makes class fun, interesting and beneficial.
No Comments
smartest woman I've ever met -- brillent --
stresses the real importance of philosophy and is unafraid to give it the edge it deserves. very knowledgable and able to break down ideas coherently. willing to discuss almost any issue.
No Comments
Very energetic, even in her earliest classes.
Excellent sense of humor, makes students think for themselves.
He's passionate and clearly communicate the subject of logic. One of my favorite courses.
Ali has a lot of flexibility and goes out of his way to help you. I recommend this class!

He responds extremely quick to emails (less than 24 hours for me). We used TopHat, and I found the quizzes to be slightly challenging. You have to make an appointment for his office hours, but he was not difficult to get a hold of. I also enjoyed his feedback on my exams because they explained in detail why the answers are they way they are.
This is challenging and fun. Ali has been a great instructor and always takes time to explain questions. Would recommend

You'll learn a lot, but he makes you work for it. Lots of lectures in class, so if you skip you'll fall behind. Quizzes are taken with peers, so those aren't too bad, but you need to pay attention anyways. Sometimes he can be confusing in his lectures, so you need to read the textbook multiple times to understand. He's passionate and nice, though!

Very easy to understand and incredibly chill, honestly first like two lectures I thought he was a young TA. Takes things really slow and makes a strong point to make sure people understand, and is funny at times. Honestly probably my favorite class of the semester. Super lax and good community built.

He's not the most engaging teacher, it can be hard to pay attention during lectures, but his assignments aren't too hard and he makes himself accessible for help with any paper or quiz. Definitely cares about your mental health, and he's a down to earth guy, so props for that.

Ali is pretty cool and flexible. I really hate philosophy but he made it tolerable and understandable. Online can be a bit hard, especially for me as a visual learner, but if you really try, you can pass.

Professor Roth is very knowledgeable in his field and delivers interesting lectures. His class is not difficult and assignments are graded leniently. Overall, I found his class to be both enjoyable and rewarding.

Professor Roth is great at teaching the material. However, his grading is not conducive to the learning process & neither are his class discussions. He is obsessed with semantics & gives poor grades regardless of if students followed instructions to the T. Would not rec.

Professor Roth, above all, is effective at honing and challenging your philosophical skills. Though he and I disagreed on most points, and he was critical on papers, I became less naïve because of him. He will show you what doing philosophy looks like and will moderate your ego. I am indebted to him for a great amount of my philosophical progress.

At first, I was concerned about this class because of the mixed RMP reviews. But as the class went on, it warms up and becomes a lot more accommodating, and Professor Roth is unexpectedly funny in his lectures. The essays are graded harshly even for a philosophy course, but if you put in the work, you can get a high grade. Roth is great!

Ok, so I took Abe for PHILOS3000 and not a well-structured class what so ever. It was almost like he was learning the material at the same time we were - like genuinely. There were never any counter argument readings to the ones he chose, which definitely does not help facilitate discussion. However, he is a sweet man, very laid back. Boring tho.

Well, he is very knowledgeable in his field. However, I feel that he had some trouble delivering the ideas to the students. He talked about one concept for the whole lecture and I was still very confused about that concept. I like him as a person, but I probably will not take his classes again.
I found his lectures quite boring and repetitive and it really turned me away from philosophy. He was also very rude when asked about his vague grading system.

Passionate about the material and very willing to talk about it with you. Receptive to student desires for course direction. Grading rather opaque and a bit harsh but fair.  Considerably helped the development of my philosophical skills.

Lectures were really repetitive but at least he clearly went over the material that he expected you to know to the point where reading the text isn't really necessary. The grade was only composed of two short response exams and two papers but he was somewhat a lenient grader.

If you take good notes and come to class everyday and use what you learned and the readings to write the papers you will get an A. Study his notes too for the test. Easy class if you come to class everyday.
I would walk 4 miles in sub-zero temps to attend Dr. Roth's dissertation seminar.

Dr. Roth is an excellent professor. It is obvious that he is passionate about the material and loves what he does. He's always friendly and happy to discuss any of the class materials. If you enjoy class participation Roth would be a good fit for you.

I had Abe for Philosophy of Action and the class was excellent.  Very enthusiastic professor, loves the material as well as teaching it. Didn't do as well as I would have liked, but that was my fault, not his.  Some of the comments on here are pretty harsh, I don't understand it.

His lectures are very disorganized which is partly due to the subject matter, but mostly due to Prof. Roth's teaching style.  Wait until AFTER class discussion to do the reading for the week since it will make much more sense.  Very difficult to predict how he will grade papers.

A. Roth is a smart guy, but he's not a very good lecturer.  Many times he spoke about the same concept for an hour or more. The students often become zombies during lecture, very boring, uninteresting topics are covered. He did screen movies and provide pizza, outside of class, however. Two papers and an exam (10 short answer). Not recommended.

I came into this class expected a lot of interesting debate. Not the case. Instead you talk about ancient philosophers. Very dull class, lectures are long and at times very pointless. Course is comprised of two short essays and a ten questions final exam. He will almost never agree with what your write.
Not the best professor.  He isn't very clear in class, but if you go to his office hours he's extremely helpful.  The lectures are hard to stay awake in, and the class is very disorganized.

Professor Roth at times comes across as cocky and arrogant, often pushing his views as the absolute truth.  However, he allows for open discussion of the primary sources and does a good job in explaining the materials read.  Class would have been a lot harder had he not taken the time to make good notes for the class.  I would recommend taking him.

Kind of follows the text. Randomly takes attendance. Does not make any sense while teaching. I really looked forward to philosophy before I started taking it. Grades the papers erratically. Horrible, horrible class, is bringing my high GPA down no matter how hard I try.

Dr. Heydari Fard was an excellent professor. I had her for Rational Choice Theory back in Spring of 2023. She is passionate about what she teaches, values discussions, and breaks things down for all of us to understand. She was accessible outside of class and is willing to help students succeed.

Abt 20pages reading for each class. 2 short paper + 1 grp presentation for undergrads. ppr revision encouraged.
Rules and boundaries are v clear but not rigid. 
Sahar is good at teaching. She's funny & assertive, patient & passionate. She's good at understanding where students are. She cares for deeper, more thorough understanding & compassion.

He's a loud New Yorker who loves yelling about what art is, is obsessed with his wife and his 'kitty cat', and loves music. Need I say more?
I had so much fun with the discussions around the lecture hall at the end of each class, he really loved hyping up each of our contributions and going on and on about them. There's a lot to read, but it's fun!

Professor Kraut is one of the nicest people I have ever met. His lectures are always engaging and worth listening to. The material was tough to grasp but if you put true effort, you'll do good on the exams. Overall, there were 2 midterms, 1 paper and a final exam. He's an extremely funny and passionate person who just genuinely loves to teach.

Your overall grade is based on 1 paper, 2 midterms, and 1 final. I assume that everyone does very poorly on the midterms because a 44% was curved to a C. The lectures are not recorded and he speaks very fast. There are no notes posted online. You never know what grade you have in the class because grades aren't posted. Don't take this awful class.

I took this class as a GE and can't care less about art, but his lectures were very engaging and made you want to care. Highly recommend it for a good time, just 2 exams and one final paper. read the textbook!!!

This man gets so off topic, requires so much reading, and expects you to not have a life inside his classroom. Cusses at students to no end before class even starts about not listening to him, and literally screams at students and belittles them for even looking at a phone. yikes.

Makes his courses more difficult than STEM classes. Wants students to read 100 pages from 17th century philosophers. Not realistic as its hard to understand. Extremely rude to students and makes fun of them during class lectures.

I took this class as a GE recently. While professor Kraut was an amazing lecturer, I found myself seriously struggling in this course. The lectures do not coincide with the exams and the exams are extremely detailed and difficult. If you are looking to get an easy A, I do not recommend.

Kraut was probably the most entertaining lecturer that I had at Ohio State. Great, funny, engaging lectures and discussions. The course is remarkably interesting. Though the class is fast paced and there is a lot to read, the assignments are fair and are not too difficult.

Dr. Kraut is a true gem. That being said, he and I just didn't jive- his teaching style was not how I learn best and our senses of humor clashed. One class I asked a question, his explanation didn't make sense, yet he kept repeating the same explanation over and over but louder each time- legit made me cry in class with how stupid he made me feel.

Kraut cares deeply about the subject matter which makes for a much more exciting GE. Participate in class because it helps with your grade at the end. I never bought the books, most of the readings are online.

Professor Kraut cares a lot about the material and wants you to be engaged in the lectures. I found the lectures very interesting and did not have to read the material because most of it was covered in class. You have to pay close attention though.
A friend and mentor

Professor Kraut is the best this University has to offer. He cares about the material and his students, and gives incredibly funny and educational lectures. He often devotes most of his class to answering student questions about the readings. His tests are fairly difficult. His papers were graded generously by the TA in this course.

Professor Kraut is easily one of the best teachers at ohio state, and I mean that sincerely. He will engage you like no other and get you wrapped up in the material. One of the funniest guys ever. However, with all this greatness comes his difficulty: he is somewhat moody will sometimes just get angry. If you can look past this, he's among the best

One of the best professors I've had in my college career. He's genuinely interested in engaging his students and getting you into the material. Hilarious, too. You have to work for your grade, but he's fair. Highly recommended.

Prof. Kraut is an amazing guy with fun stories and wild tendencies. His class is very interesting, the material is compelling, but it's all near ruined by three surprisingly difficult multiple choice tests and a harshly graded paper. As someone who feels the understood/engaged with all the material quite well, my grades did not reflect this.

Kraut is very obviously one of the most engaged professors at the university. He cares about all his material and each of his students. He's also incredibly smart and well-educated. His expertise in various fields is constantly surprising.
Great Lectures.

Professor Kraut is both knowledgeable and enthusiastic.  He has no rigid lectures but adjusts to class flow and interest. I took this class only as LSAT prep, but it was such an experience that had I taken it earlier, I would have switched to a Phil mjaor. TIP: mention music theory or cats to illustrate class concepts - he'll love it.
Extradiornary

On my way to a PH.D (not in philosophy) I had Kraut as an undergrad. He is not only an amazing lecturer, but he is movie-star good. This guy should be at Oxford or Princeton, based on his pedagogical wizardry. A Kraut class is a strange yet highly informative experience that will change your life! Kind of like a Cohen brother's movie on acid.

Kraut is funny, but not a great teacher.  He's entertaining to listen to, but the stuff he talks about in class seems irrelavant on the exams.  All I can say is READ.  It's the only way to really understand what each philosopher is saying.
Great lecuturer.  Hard midterms although final was easier.  if you have a good TA you should do just fine if you attend lecture.
Incredibly awesome teacher.  Extremely passionate about subject.  Awesome class.

Kraut's metaphysics class is perhaps the most entertaining, engaging class I have ever had, though it is extraordinarily taxing. Kraut is an engaging, helpful teacher and discussion leader and always willing to go above and beyond to help students.

Kraut is an intelligent man and a brilliant philosopher but a poor teacher that not interested in his students. He did not come to class prepared and covered it up with youtube videos and irrelevant philosophical rants. The material was difficult but he gave little help. I recieved a B in the class but I feel as though I have learned nothing.
He is a hard lecturer and exams are curved but that is because they are very challenging.  Your best bet is to pick somone else

Great professor, really engaging! He cares a great deal about the topics and really wants to get the class interested and involved. Really personable and enjoys students who utilize office hours. Come with anything to say and he'll have a conversation and make you think. Great class to take b/c we discuss current philosophical issues

Kraut is great.  His class was always fun, and if you participate and say something halfway intelligent, you quickly become a favorite.  This class is not for the meek or the shy.    If you are willing to fight for your point, either with him or another student, he loves it.

Kraut is an intellect, and a flim flam man who reinvents himself. Biggest coup was as a record engineer who made 60s hit, "Red Rubber Ball," by "The Cyrkle."  Kraut would invoke the "spectre of Hendrix" in fervid tones. Now, he's a jazzer. I participated, and got an A-.  9 months later, he did not know me, and refused me a letter of recommendation.

He seems unorganized but really does have a good handle on epistemological issues. If you want to think about philosophy in a way that is relative to your life then you'll love Kraut. He is willing to work with you outside of class to make sure you understand. I thought he was a great teacher because I learned a lot from taking his class.

Didn't organize the class very well, and didn't always seem to have much more a grasp on the material than the students. Kept everyone engaged in the material, and was a really personable and made for a fun class, but the class would've been better if I felt like I learned more.
Funny, smart, and generally cool. Peppers conversation with relevant anecdotes. Obviously has a life outside class. Gotta love him.
funniest prof. I've had in a while. Found him way more approachable than other teachers.
Most engaged teacher I have had while at OSU. Although by far the most arrogant one. He makes the information interesting with his rants. However come exam time, your basically screwed.

Arrogant ****, only cared about himself and jazz music.  Treated students like idiots if they didn't agree with him, not condusive for a philo class.  I honestly think that he thinks he is smarter than the philosophers we were studying.

The man is brilliant.  But he's so arrogant it's hard to listen to him for 2 hours.  Often complains about people being not as smart as he is, and if you disagree with him, obviously you're an idiot.  Unless you feel like sucking up to a pompous jerk for 10 weeks, go for another prof.
Hard.  He definately plays favorites, so that's annoying.  Interesting class, just expect your GPA to take a big hit.

Great class.  One of the best professors I've ever had, and is the best at communicating his ideas clearly.  Always available to talk to students after class and help them.  Doesn't mean class is easy because you need to work your butt off, but definately worth it.
No Comments
best prof ever. period.
Still the best professor I ever had, ten years later. My first favorite class ever.
very clear, great at getting his point across and funny to boot.  i was already thinking of majoring in philosophy when i started attending osu, but taking kraut's intro class sealed the deal.

Kraut is an eccentric guy to say the least, hilarious, which to me made him all the easier to pay attention to. He knows what he's talking about and is good at saying things that leave you wondering whether or not you should be laughing.

Kraut is by far the best prof I've had recently.  He is passionate about the class and about making sure his students are engaged.  I adore the man - take whatever you can with him.  (and I took his class outside of my major!)
Hilarious, smart, and a great teacher, the best prof I've had.  If you have a chance, definitely take one of his classes.
A class with Kraut is probably one of the best classes you can take. Tests are hard, though.
Awsome teacher, awsome class, Prof Kraut always kept the material interesting and tangible to the class.
One of the best professors that I have had.  Really engaged the material, although he was very opinionated, he cared what others had to say.  If you are quiet, he can be a little intimidating.
best teacher ive had
very opinionated and full of himself. yet he is amusing. i learned more from reading the books/handouts though
best instructor i've ever had
Kraut is hillarious, intelligent, witty, and keeps students engaged in the material/entertained.  He should have his own talk show or something.  Sweet Jesus!  I am **** with Kraut-ian adoration!
hilarious, smart as hell, gets the whole class going
The dude even makes Symbolic Logic fun. Take the hell out of this man's classes.
No Comments
Awesome
Super sexy
awesome guy, good discussions

Professor D'Arns is obviously very knowledgeable regarding the course material and is good at explaining complex theories in simple terms using examples. He does not allow technology to be used in class, but I almost find that better as his handouts each class are very helpful. Study guides for 3 exams are very clear. The 2 papers are manageable.

Prof D'Arms is a good lecturer and I learned a lot in his class. However, he didn't make an effort to get to know his students' names. When he called on someone, there seemed to be a disconnect between what they were saying and what he said in response. However, it was an easy class and I will use these frameworks for my entire life, probably.
Class was lecture heavy with lots of readings and notes, but study guides were clear. Papers were less clear but still do-able.
Professor D'Arms is a kind and patient professor, he explain philosophical ideas very well! Just do not forget to start doing readings and reading reflections earlier!

Professor D'Arms is a great professor and is very passionate about ethics. He is very clear about what he is teaching and his homework correlates exactly to his lectures. The only thing is that his exams are all written, so you have to study for them. Lecture is optional, but recitation is mandatory. Overall interesting class!

Professor Darms gives such long lectures and jumps around topics so much you never know what hes talking about. This 2000 level class was way more work than any of the 5000 level classes I was taking. If you asked him any kind of question or how to explain himself he wouldn't be able to and graded way too harshly since he cant explain himself.
Easily one of the best instructors at OSU.  Clear explanations, ability to synthesize authorslit, and genuinely interested in probing materials to see where they can develop.

Professor D'Arms is a great lecturer. His class wasn't easy, but he explains the material well and is helpful during office hours. If you want a challenge, he really makes you think and work hard. Overall, he is an intelligent professor and I recommend taking his courses.
He is great, So intelligent and very good at conveying interesting but hard topics

Professor DArms was extremely dull in class. He handled touchy questions well. When it comes down to it though he is uninterested in teaching. I visited his office hours frequently and he couldn't remember who I was when I emailed him. The syllabus was short and vague and left much up to question. Avoid this professor if you can.
This was my favorite class that I've taken at OSU and I'm a third year physics major.  Discussions were thorough and thoughtful and changed the way I look at things.  Not an easy class, though.

D'Arms was just a plain good teacher. We dealt with really sensitive stuff but he tried to stay away from his own opinions. He'll steer you toward life-changing ideas and it's worth the brain-bending.
He is very good at moderating discussions and handling sensitive responses, an important quality to have when teaching about ethics.
He is awesome. Dead serious. Take this class, with this teacher. Best class I've ever taken.
Very good at clarifying texts which sometimes seem incomprehensible.  I found it best to read the text after he already explained it, that way you won't be frustrated for hours on end.

after surviving 130, I must say that Dr. D'arms is still a relatively nice teacher. The class got amazingly boring however over halfway through the class; though assignments were easy, I think reading level and lack of a syllabus were a bit much
I liked the class a lot.  He was very clear in his lectures and always willing to help students
Very smart... funny, and great to talk to out of class.

Knows the subject well; teaches with clarity. Most importantly, he is humble and down-to-earth, unlike other professors who are more arrogant. When he does not have answers, he will admit so and will work out the problem with you. This is very rare! He's
No Comments
Professor Jorati gives amazing lectures (you can tell she's passionate and knows her stuff)

Lectures are not mandatory and few attended, as all they did was review the readings. In terms of work: interesting and light reading, with one weekly online quiz, and three total papers. That's it. That being said, I was not particularly fond of the papers, but that's not a huge deal. Overall, great teacher and good class. Recommend.

I took PHIL-321 and PHIL-592 with Julia. She is amazing. She knows the primary text in an extremely skilled way as if she can tell you the pages by memory. Very clear organization of the whole class. Attainable tasks. The workload she assigns every week is just perfect. A-must take in Phil Department in Five Colleges.

This class was really easy for a 4 credit course. The workload was manageable and attendance was not necessary but helped. All of the quizzes were based on the readings - as long as you did the readings, it was an easy A. A couple of papers, but nothing too hard. Overall, Jorari was really nice and engaging and I would highly recommend this class.
The lectures that she gives are very clear and engaging. You can tell that she's passionate about the material and wants students to succeed

Interesting and engaging lectures, organized notes (easy to follow slides), many extra credit opportunities, Prof. Jorati seems very knowledgeable and passionate about philosophy. Weekly quizzes were all multiple choice and quite straightforward. I would def recommend, some of the things we learned will definitely stay with me.

Julia has true passion for her subject and loves engaging with her student's perspective. She manages to accomplish this in a non condescending way, exploring ideas very charitably. I recommend everybody take at least one philosophy class during their time at UMass, and Julia is the best introduction you can get to the subject.

a decent amount of various readings ( optional readings too ). lectures and lecture notes were always posted after class. weekly online open note quizzes. prof is clearly interested in the material and holds good lectures

Few assignments.  Has TA's grade the assignments.  Class material was very interesting and lecture was great, but challenging to receive a good grade.  She is a quiet spoken lady and many people would be bored out of their minds, so don't choose if you're not interested.  She is very smart and you can learn a lot from her if you want to.
Very few grades, very boring class. I got an A- without trying. But you HAVE to show up to pass. The papers and short assignments are easy if you pay attention just a little.  Just so so boring.

Professor Jorati means well, but she finds a way to make an easy class somewhat difficult.  Very few grades, and most of the assigned readings that you do throughout the semester don't even matter in the end.
Super chill, super knowledgeable, really glad I got him

Jason DeWitt is a young professor but seems to know exactly how to do everything right when it comes to teaching. His ability to answer questions about hard topics and explain them to students clearly was amazing. He is also lenient and very relatable when he taught. Wish I had another class with him.

Loved DeWitt. Gives interesting lectures and makes it easy to participate. Fair grader and is willing to work with you- I was able to review my papers and got feedback that always helped me on the following ones. Pay attention in lectures and take some general notes and you will do well. Very much wish I could take him again- I learned a lot.

Hes very nice an lenient, funny guy. His classes are discussion based and there is a participation grade, but he makes the classes interesting so theres no worry there. Hes very flexible and works with you with any issue you have. Id loved this class and would love to have him as my professor again

Writing this feels like beating a dead horse. Professor Tenant is, like others mentioned, very smart but is not the greatest teacher. He goes off on tangents, rambles about unrelated topics, and almost seems to show off by doing unnecessary proofs. He does curve pretty well though, it's at least +8% but I'm guessing it's probably +10%.

This class felt all over the place, and generally wasn't worth the effort. The lectures aren't prepared in advance at all, and it just felt like we were talking about random stuff every class period. When it came time to do the papers, I struggled with the topics since they were presented very poorly in lecture. Please don't take this class.

Tennant is fine. The lectures are sort of useless beyond the first 25 minutes, because he rambles. He is clearly an incredibly smart guy, but not very good at teaching introductory logic because he can't simplify complex topics. If you go to TA office hours, you will have no problems. Plus, a very generous curve at the end of the course helps.

While obviously brilliant, Professor Tennant's teaching style and vernacular don't suffer fools. Prepare for a serious course in a rigorous methodology. Groups outside of class and office hours (particularly with the TA) are an absolute must. Practice, practice, practice, and then still hope you're getting anywhere.

He's an incredible intellect, passionate, and gives a great curve. However, the way he formats his grading contrasts heavily with his pace. If he gave easier quizzes and made the midterm actually fair, it would have been more forgiving on how often he sidetracks. This schedule and his heavy, academic speech make it far too difficult to thrive.

Like others have said, Tennant is very clearly exceptionally knowledgeable of this field, which is evident from his lectures. However, this level of expertise is not something that he seems to be able to pare down for students in introductory logic classes like 2500. If you take this class, be prepared to learn from YouTube and other such sources.

Lack of structure; most stuff aren't useful unless outside logist career.
He doesn't remember what he has covered and what he hasn't. Each lec jumps between multiple unnumbered slides. 
Class average around 50%, waved to look better. But still, didn't learn much.

Hyperacademic, doesn't define anything, lectures useless until the 2nd listen, and only if you had the TA already explain everything to you. Quizzes are ridiculously hard. None of them had an average above a 70 I don't think. The fact that he is teaching is beyond me. He's smart and "qualified," but he has none of the soft skills to be a teacher.
Please listen to the reviews and avoid this class!!!! I tried to give him a chance but he's incredibly convoluted and dismissive towards students

Please, I beg, do not take this mans entry level class. Impossibly over complicated, you will not understand a word of whats going on and have to do all of the real learning by watching other peoples lectures on YT to get the core concepts. Does not listen to class feedback. Uses words you will not understand, that do not enrich the material.

Hardest intro class Ive ever taken in my life. I took this class just to learn more about philosophy and I am kicking my past self. Lectures dont make sense and his own textbook is hard to follow. I think hes too smart to be a professor and doesnt understand this is an intro class with people that have never taken philosophy before.

For an intro level class for students with no philosophy background this class ridiculously hard! do NOT take this class with him. He is a very smart guy but almost too smart to teach this class. You will not learn the material and then only have 4 assignments make up your entire grade. making it really easy for your grade to drop quickly

Please dont take this class. I gave him the benefit of the doubt when I read his reviews before because I needed to take the class and I wish I wouldve listened. Hes fairly nice but way too advanced for intro. Only 4 grades total, 2 papers (10% of grade) and a midterm (30% of grade) and final (50% of grade) and secret grade adjustments after

Absolutely do not take this class if you want a good GPA. There are only 4 assignments (2 essays, midterm, and final) for the whole semester. Grading takes absolutely forever so you won't know what you need on the final, which is 50% of the grade, before taking it because he takes forever to grade. By far the worst class I've taken and I took Chem.

The worst professor I've ever had in college. He does not care about his students at all. His grading criteria is a secret. You never know why you get an F, and you also never know how he curves you at the end. You can turn in your paper draft and get his feedback, but you may still get a C at the end. Don't buy his books, you will never use them.

The guy is fun, and tells crazy amazing stories. Probably the best professor Ive learned from at osu and Im a neuroscience major. Just go there, listen to the stories, and review the main concepts from the slideshows afterwards and pass. Probably gonna get a rec letter from him

Basically you have 4 assignments in the whole course. 2 papers each worth 10%, 30% for a midterm, and 50% for a final. Barely any work, not too much reading, just write well. Come to lecture for attendance and he is fun to listen to about his travels around the world, Europe, India, Iran, Africa, this man is a great story teller.

Neil is an absolute genius. Loves to teach and pushes you to the limit. Everyone bombs the exams, but he curves it to everyone's advantage, so really, don't stress it. Go to lecture. Go to office hours. READ the text he gives you. You WILL fail otherwise. You can expect his courses to be the most difficult you've ever taken, but it's worth it.

Professor Tennant is very energetic and you can tell that he truly loves teaching symbolic logic.  He tends to throw a great deal of material at you and expects you to pick it up immediately, but he is more than willing to help you understand it.  He will do all that he can to break things down for you to understand so that you can preform better.
Neil is a world renowned Philosopher... Sometimes the things he says is just out of the league for an intro class so it can be confusing. Easy class though, you only have two papers and two midterms

He's British, between his accent and the stories he told lectures were fairly entertaining. He is specific about attendance, for example a kid got up and walked out of lecture right after signing the attendance sheet going around, and he made a point to stop class to address how rude it was.

Brilliant guy who loves the material. Has a tendency to go off into tangents. The tests (only two, and they're the only grades in the class) are brutal, but he curves heavily. Office Hours are practically mandatory, but are helpful.  The textbook (by him and therefore free) rarely gets mentioned, but is important to read if you wanna pass.

As a tenured professor, wants this class to be more than a gen ed credit. The material is hard to wrap your head around no matter how many times you reread the readings. Office hours are mandatory to receive a decent grade. Grades papers extremely slowly. Grade is based on three papers, final is worth 50% of final grade.

He is very intelligent and passionate about his field and I respect that. However, his teaching skills are horrendous. I could never make out exactly what he was trying to say during lecture because he uses unnecessarily big words and goes off on multiple tangents. Papers and midterms  take a long time to  be graded.

Prof. Tennant is one of the most brilliant people I've ever met, and he's funny.  Unfortunately, he's probably the worst professor I've ever had.  He goes off into extremely complex tangents during lecture, he doesn't respond to emails, and he isn't good at explaining things simply.  But he is willing to try to help during office hours.

He graded hard and sent out an email at the end of the course saying we were dumb and 'generation wuss'. He also said we should look for education outside the US because they clearly don't have standards here.
One of the best professors I have ever had.

One of the most intelligent professors I have ever had at OSU. He knows exactly what he is teaching just isn't good at conveying it in large lecture. The midterm and final are extremely hard but there is a hefty curve to the class. Taking 1100 first was useful and he is VERY helpful in office hours

Quite honestly the worst professor I've ever had at OSU.  He definitely knows the material, but his presentation is nearly impossible to comprehend, yet he seems surprised when students ask for help. The average for the midterm was somewhere in the F range. He goes off-topic frequently and his TA was stand-offish and unhelpful.

He went on a lot of tangents and whatnot but despite this his lectures were packed with information.  He said it himself some days, he has no clue why he is teaching an entry level course but I did enjoy the fact that it wasn't the clichè wishy washy entry level philosophy course people joke about.
Wonderful! He's so much fun and gets sidetracked so easily, but somehow we still get everything done and understand it well!
Great Job, learned a lot.

This class was impossible to follow and hard to understand. He went on long and seemingly endless tangents that, in the end, had nothing to do with what we were learning. He's an amazingly intelligent man, but not fit for a lower level class. I wouldn't recommend him for low levels, but for high levels he is probably wonderful.
More work than you would expect for a 100 level class. All of his essay questions are from lecture. Have to write 2,000 word papers.

im in his philosophy 101 class and he treats it like it isn't an intro level course.  our first assignment is an 8 page paper. this isn't awful but very difficult to write 2000 words about something i have just began learning about.  he also uses terms and phrases that i have no idea what he means.  he is smart but expects too much from a 101 class

The final paper was the only grade. I put probably 20-30 hours into the paper. I also went to all the classes, and he said in class that he would grade more favorably to those who had good attendance. I got an A but it was stressful. However, I think it was a good class. Dr. Tennant knows his stuff like you wouldn't believe and he was a great guy.

I guess I'm in the minority here, but Neil is an excellent instructor.  Challenging, yes, but that is a good thing (and, anyway, he curves).  Very entertaining and engaging lectures.  If you get confused, ask; he will help you.  Great handouts, too.  Not an easy A - but if you want to learn logic from one of the best in the world...

Neil Tennant is the most brillant professor I have ever had in my education.  However he has a very difficult time transfering his knowledge to the class because he is functioning at such an incomprehensible level.  I did not learn much about logic, but I learned a great deal of other useful theories on life.  I feel honored to have been his pupil.

I studied under Tennant for my entire degree in Scotland years ago and still regard his teaching as one of the 3 biggest positive influences on my life. Wake up and pay attention, there's a genius at work in front of you! He won't tolerate muddy thinking though, get your logic right before you argue and you'll get his respect. Awesome Prof.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH THIS PROFFESSOR.  I Had a 3.92 before his class and now i am screwed.  The majority of the class dropped, the average was somewhere in the 40's, he has no organization, makes up words, makes things literally 1000 times more complicated than need be....if you care at all about your grade or learning DO NOT TAKE HIM

Honestly, I found Tennant to be a horrible instructor. He is extremely pretentious and talks about himself way too much. He seemed very uninterested in whether or not his students were actually learning the material. There are some excellent logic teachers, but Neil is not one of them. If you care about learning and your GPA, avoid his class.

This man cannot convey logic in a comprehensible manner. If I had another teacher I would have had an A in the class. The class lost 50 out of the 80 students by the end of the quarter. If you want to take 250 and Neil Tennant is teaching it wait for another professor.

Lectures were often very close to incomprehensible, and I'm a philosophy major and got an A in the class. There's a huge curve... the average for the midterm was a 47%. I was surprised it was that high. Honestly unless you're a philosophy major, take math 150 to fulfill the requirement, you'll be better for it.
He is so hot. I **** to this guy!!!!  Our pherenomes match. Im just kidding, but I do enjoy his stories, and I really do think he's hott!
Excellent!
Arrogant and temperamental, Tennant cares much more about hearing himself talk than seeing his students learn.
okay prof.  Nothing to get too excited about.

Philosophy is a bit over my head to begin with, but he generally keeps it clear and is an amazingly engaging speaker.  I didn't do very well in the class, but that certainly wasn't his doing.  He's really a great professor!
i love the way your teach, keep up the antics, dont let a few nay sayers get ya down
Who else can keep a lecture full of half asleep college students interested?

The class may be difficult, but Tennant will stop if you need help or need to take longer on the notes. Tennant has exceeded what I expected of college profs being a first year, and I gladly would take another class with him.

Professor Tennant has exceeded my expectations (as a first year student) as to what a Professor should be. He is very eloquent, and provides helpful and humerous anecdotes for our pleasure so that we comprehend the material with ease. In such a controversial subject, Professor Tennant provides an unbiased account of all things he teaches.
I think the man is a genuis.He is quite a character. I love to hear his stories! He makes everything interesting. I really appreciate the way he teaches and I highly recommend him!
Great teacher, great anecdotes. Uses philosophy as the tool it actually is without getting lost in the wilderness of the "too" abstract thoughts. I would gladly take another course he teaches.

The good news is this class is on a curve. The bad news is this is not a very good class. It is like a math class with no structured homework. He "throws you into the deep end" from the first day and never teaches you to swim. It is like trying to figure out algebra in the first grade going from the most advanced problems to the easiest.
No Comments

A thoroughly engaging speaker, though in 650, a tad hard to follow (because number theory?  NOT my friend).  I will add that I was not a math major, and got an A in 250 and a B+ in 650, so the classes were by no means impossibly hard.

DO NOT take logic with Tennant. Questions in his class are futile because he refuses to provide simple or relevant answers and often refers to grad-level theory. He's no better in office hours...he's an arrogant person whose first priority is flaunting his knowledge, not helping his students.
I think he may be the smartest man I have ever met.  His class was hard, but with work one can still get an A.  Very intesting class.  I recommend him.

Dr. Tennant is a smart, smart man.  Perhaps too smart to teach an intro class.  A midterm and final (both in class essays).  I got a 68 on the first midterm, with the average being 75, and wrote a lot more on the final and actually got a B+ for the quarter.  Take that for what you will.

He is one of the most enlightened and intelligent proffesors at OSU. However, extreeemely liberal and somewhat unorganized. This class was really hard, like everyone in it got about a 73 pre-curve due to being totally lost. His stories about tripping on shrooms are quite entertaining though.
I took this to get out of calculus.  This was harder.  Tennant takes great delight in the fact that his exams are impossibly hard.  You need to be a math major to pass.

I felt bad dropping the class because I felt so enlightened. Unfortunately to continue your education and become truly enlightened, you need good grades and a solid F will not do. If you are not a Philos. major, no matter how hard you study you will struggle. Drop this class.
veeeery hard class

Addition: I do not mean to convey that he replies to ALL emails with one word answers, he only did to the ones I wrote to him at the end of the quarter. He has since told me that he did so because I asked him yes/no questions. Still, given my questions, better responses would have been appreciated.
Great teacher, but he demands a lot of out you on his tests, that were all essay based.  Final is short answer.  Attendance policy too.

Incredibly smart person... maybe too smart to teach an intro class like Phil. 101.  Exams are extremely difficult.  If you really have a love for Philosophy and he is your teacher you will enjoy him much more than the regular student just filling up the schedule.
One of the best Professors I have had thus far. Very funny, helpful, and smart! Everyone should have the experience of taking a class with him. Love the accent too!
interesting lectures, and makes you think about the big stuff, but takes attendance in hall of 100s of kids.  he was the SSDP advisor, what more needs to be said?
smart, smart man
I loved his stories, but I think he spent too much time telling them, and not enough time teaching, since his exams were really hard.  Very very smart man though.
He was entertaining and infamous for his tangents, but you never want to miss a class. He is actually a teacher and encourages you to think for yourself, but helps you along the way.

Such an entertaining guy!  His stories alone are worth the class...  Exams are hard, grades on a true bell curve, but he seemed to be a bit more gracious on grades in the end then he claimed he would be.

Pranav was amazing this past semester. We learned ethics topics for about half of the semester and then did debate projects. Pranav's focus is improvement, and as long as you improve from beginning to end you will get a good grade. This class is different, but it was good for a history GE.

Pranav is one of the few professors at OSU who cares more about improvement than individual grades. I was a little anxious about this class since it involved two group debates. But Pranav coached us really well, and I felt like I improved as a thinker and public speaker. Highly recommend Pranav's Intro to Ethics!

Professor Pranav Ambardekar's innovative teaching approach stands out. 
Mini-papers + engaging discussions = Real philosophy in action!
Flexibility in assessments + extra credit options were commendable. 
Attendance = vital. 
Class = discussion-based sessions.
Best professor for deep insights, interactive learning, and skill development.

Professor Ambardekar was my favorite professor at OSU. I would be excited to wake up and come to his class, knowing it would entail an intellectually intriguing discussion. While he knows the material well, he also cares deeply about it. If I or anyone else had trouble with a concept, he would patiently go over it again. 

I recommend PHILOS 2465
One of the best courses I've taken at Ohio State!

Pranav is a great professor. He truly does care about every one of his students and simply wants them to learn. Rather than focusing on the grade Pranav just wants to see you be engaged and eager to learn. If you do that you will learn a ton, get a good grade, and become friends with him.

He is an amazing professor who is able to teach information in the class effectively and cares if his students are struggling with a certain topic and their learning experience. He is very reasonable and understanding about deadlines and as long as you put in effort in the class and care about learning, you will receive a good grade.

Pranav is the GOAT. The lectures were amazing and informative with a lot of "mind blown" moments. There is a good amount of reading and a fair bit of writing but he makes very clear that as long as you try, you'll get a good grade. I'm surprised this was his first class ever since he was such a great instructor.

ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! Prof Ambardekar is one of the best teachers ever! His lectures are so spot-on that you will understand the readings easily. You still need to work hard but his class is so organized you'll never have an issue with anything other than content. He is accessible, very passionate, and is more focused on improvement than just A's.

This is for PHILOS 2456 which was not an option for this review. By the end of the semester, your grade still says N/A in Carmen, so throughout the semester you don't know where your grade sits. Your entire grade is pretty much dependent upon 3 papers. There is no rubric, so you won't know what you missed or why you received the grade you did.
Genius.

Not many oppurtunities s to gain points so just don't screw up your essays! Only three essays assigned and not hard but the lack of assignments mean you can't slack on any of them. Very chill professor and allows for discussion and doesn't just talk at you. Only met online once a week which was nice.
A decent guy teaching a decent class.

I loved this class. Declan's teaching style was really well organized and he balanced lecture perfectly with class discussion. And he is English, so his accent really adds to the entertainment factor of the class.

The worst professor I have ever had at OSU in 4 years. Totally inconsiderate forcing everyone to speak even when not required. Has extremely high expectations for a GE. Participation grading is the worst part, just forget about it! Avoid him and save yourself.

Aaron is my favorite professor, and this class will change your life. He'll give you great feedback so that you'll improve, but he makes it easy to get a good grade by letting you redo assignments. I don't know how to explain it, but the classroom sometimes felt like hanging out with a group of friends even though we were working hard.
Not a very challenging professor. He really wants his students to succeed so he makes it easy to do so. Weekly readings are not great, but I often didn't read them and I managed to get by.

Can't say enough good about him!!! Funny in an awkward kind of way, also incredibly smart. Syllabus seems hardcore, but he is not, he is super accommodating and kind. Pretty easy class, but also incredibly philosophical and borderline life changing. Everything learned in this class is valuable outside of the class, especially in today's society.
super chill class cool dude
He was just painfully average and not very on top of things.

Were a lot of readings, but you should be fine skipping some of you pay attention to the lectures. The tests just went over what was said in lectures and you are allowed to skip a couple questions. The essays and research papers were not too hard and were graded pretty generously.
2 lectures with weekly quizzes, exam and project is straightforward. Lectures were concise and easy to understand. If you take notes and attend lectures, should have no problem getting an A.
He keeps things entertaining and accessible and it's an easy A if you engage with the material and class, and take good notes.

He's a nice guy, but is very bad with using Canvas and doesn't allow much room for us to make mistakes. I say this because he made so many mistakes with posting, grading, and announcements throughout the semester.

It was his first time teaching engineering ethics when I took him and I thought he did the best he could, given he had no engineering background. The one thing that annoyed me was that he didn't post lectures notes online after class, so if you didn't write down everything in class you were SOL on pop quizzes and the exam.

Scott's a good dude. I hated this class because I hate philosophy, but as a teacher he's not bad at all, and he can be pretty funny at times. My only warning is to prep well for the final. He made it sound like it wouldn't be very hard during class, so I didn't study very much, but when we actually got it I felt a little unprepared.
Engineering ethics, was semi-interesting material, as it could drag at times, but Prof did a good job of keeping it  fun and interesting. Great professor

Harkema was AWESOME! Super funny and entertaining, he kept me engaged the whole lecture! He was lighthearted with the projects he had us do, and met with me outside of class when I has some questions. I was super scared to take a class with almost all 3rd/4th year engineering bros but it has been my favorite class at osu so far! Long live scotty:)

He tries to be personable with students since the class is structured to invite discussion but you'll easily find the material boring which I don't fault him for. Pay attention to the syllabus since not all readings are required (for the quizzes).

If you pay attention he's easy to follow and understand. He really tried to engage his student's in discussion. it was interesting to hear everyone's perspective on issues. He added a humorous component to a class that could be morbid.
Scott Harkema was a great professor. Really cares about his students and really works to help you understand the material. It can be a bit challenging, but very rewarding in the end.
Do not take PHILOS 1500 if Scott is teaching it. This is the hardest class I've taken at OSU. He makes the coursework so unnecessarily hard for a GE.

this class is structured in 4 large portions and if you fail (as in you must receive a 100%) one section, you cannot move on to the rest. extremely difficult grading not to mention he doesn't explain the material that well to begin with. wouldn't recommend it if you need an intro to philosophy ge. I couldn't even get past week 3 it was so difficult
Great Prof!

Brown is arguably one of the worst professors l've had. He's "proud" of developing this course, but it's structured awfully. There are 2 weekly readings (~15 pages) and a reading quiz for each. He likes to make the questions hyperspecific, and even if the class disagrees with an answer, he won't change it. He will also penalize you for dumb things.

Brown is a... unique professor who seems to want to penalize students with unclear and varying grading standards. For a class that he developed himself, he does not seem to be proficient at actually teaching it, and forces the course to be a lot more serious than it needs to be for a GE. Essentially, help yourself and take the separate courses.

Honestly, the reviews scared me at first, but he's really not as bad as everyone says. He can be a bit kooky and the lectures are a little ramble-y but if you do the readings and talk in class, you'll get a good grade.

Long weekly reading and reflection, but I do enjoy most of the selections. Class is mainly discussion based. There's also a semester long research project, but there's recitation every week to keep you on track. Strict attendance policy. Don't take this class if you just want an easy GE because this class has a lot of work but I do like it

PHILOS 1338 is worth 4 credits and so a lot of the difficulty is warranted. Professor Brown unfortunately has a style of teaching this class that I dislike. Very strict about attendance, gives random pop quizzes in class time to time, and is a tough grader of all exams, presentations, etc. The homework is to read a lot and it is a LOT of reading.

Eh. I liked him, glad to have his class over with though. The actual work isn't that much, just a weekly reading and reflection, though you do have to show up to almost every class on time and stay through the lecture. He's strict about attendance. If you're good at reading comprehension and writing, you'll do fine.

Scott started off nice, but as the add/drop period ended, he turned mean. He often penalized reasonably punctual students, his rubric is unclear, and his grading is questionable. He randomly offered a curve because people were not meeting his awfully harsh standards for the presentation. Please do not take any class with him as an instructor.
Worst professor I have ever taken at OSU. Keeps deleting my reviews. This is my sixth time writing this. Don't take his class. Weird guy with eccentric habits
TERRIBLE! RARELY READ EMAILS, PUTS IN GRADES LAST MINUTE, DEDUCTS SO MANY POINTS OFF!!! DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS PLS TAKE THE EASIER OPTIONS!! EVERY TIME I WAS IN THIS CLASS I WANTED TO CRY
Avoid at all cost if you want to maintain a good GPA.
Please Stay Away. He Wants You To Fail.
