Look there are a lot of negative reviews here because Scott is a tough grader. However, Scott genuinely is a smart guy that cares a lot about you learning the content. Don't expect an easy GE credit, but if you want a deeper understanding of ethics and philosophy, this is your guy.
Difficult class. Would not recommend

(P1) Scott Brown flagged my previous review out of spite because his ratings are so low.
(P2) My previous rating was valid criticism and abides by the site's guidelines.
(P3) His future students won't be able to see what a horrible professor he is.
(C) Scott Brown advocates for censorship and doesn't want to improve his teaching skills :(
Repost #4

I took this class a couple semesters ago and in the beginning, this was my favorite class on campus... It is very heavily dependent on group discussion and debate which I tend to enjoy... However, ironically (for a philosophy class), he grades under the premise he agrees with you, not whether it's valid. The presentation is rough.

I made an account just so I could write this review and warn future students DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. I spent hours and days on almost every assignment to then get borderline C's on each one. He is the harshest grader and very subjective. As others have said, his rubric and grading are inconsistent and the assigned readings are WEIRD.

As you might know, this professor teaches an intro philosophy class for CS majors. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Take philos 1332 with cse 2501 instead. Scott brown treats his class like a 5000 level class and he asks for a ridiculous amount of participation and attendance for what should be an 'easy' genEd.

I believe that Scott wants his class to fail. First, if you are 10 seconds late, he will mark you off. Second, there are pop quizzes and he grades them very harshly. I forgot to put a comma and he took off 7 POINTS!! Third, he expects you to talk and write like a philosopher even though he knows that we are not philosophy major. AVOID THIS GUY

All of the hard work (presentation & essays) in this 4 credit hour course is also assigned in the 1 credit hour CSE 2501 course. This course will negatively affect your GPA for no reason at all. If you want to concentrate on more important courses, take 2501 and some easy 3 credit hour engineering philosophy course.

This class takes up too much of your time. Such topics covered in class shouldn't really require pop quizzes, discussions, and presentations. The guy has a sick mentality on how this class should be taught. It's not worth your time. Again, listen to the advice on this website and take the other alternatives.
Do not enroll, drop this class. Trust me, you'll thank me later. Just take an easy 'Cultures & Ideas' gened course and CSE 2501 and you're set for an easy LIFE.

Avoid at all costs. I would highly highly recommend taking 2501 + Another Ethics class instead of taking 1338 with Brown. Grading is very harsh. Attendance is mandatory and you get points off for missing. If you are 10 seconds late to class you get marked late. 

And there are pop quizzes for the mandatory readings.

Scott Brown lacks consistency in his grading. There is also a mindboggling amount of reading for this being a 1000 level course. Also, while I understand the purpose of the course is to cover computer ethics, we talked about porn and sex robots for way too long. I get it's technically a valid discussion for computer ethics, but Scott it's weird.

Scott is overall a pretty good professor. Although his grading is really tough (and sometimes unclear), he is always willing to help and goes the extra mile to make sure his students understand. He takes a while to respond to email, but his responses are VERY helpful. His quizzes are pretty easy but he grades the other assignments pretty harshly.

Shocked to see so much negative feedback here. Scott is a difficult grader, but also holds office hours the entire semester & is very willing to help you prepare for those bigger-point assignments. He is extremely friendly, caring, & his lectures were always very interactive and entertaining. It's as time-consuming as I expect a 4 CH course to be.

I believe Scott Brown structures this class for students to fail, never have i seen a professor grade so harshly on quizzes presentation and essays. He will take points off for the most absurd reason like body language in a presentation. He also expects for you to be a philosopher in 2 months avoid this guy if you care about your grade.
Terrible professor.

Drop the course if you want to have a good GPA. The grading is unnecessarily harsh. You will be expected to have a near-complete understanding of all the reading materials. If you seek happiness in life, avoid Scott Brown. It would be wise to start exercising to increase your sprinting speed.

I genuinely love philosophy and was part of a philosophy organization outside of OSU. The material is good, but the grading was difficult enough to crush all the fun. For your own growth as a student, take a regular ethics course and CSE 2501 until he better adjusts the class expectations. I had better outcomes from a regular ethics class.

Far and away my favorite nonmajor class I took as an undergrad at Ohio State. 
Lectures were consistently extremely interesting, well presented, and engaging. 
The only real cons to his class were:
 * Lots of out-of-class readings
 * That he is a tough (but ultimately fair) grader
Though both these things contributed to better learning.
Recommend!
Not good. Avoid this guy

His class was really interesting, but his grading was discouraging. I never had a professor that harsh on grading essays and presentations. Just be prepared to put in the work. Get feedback from him as much as you can, and spend 3 hours on each reading. His class was difficult to manage with my other CSE classes.

The course itself was quite interesting, but there are heavy readings before most of the classes. Participations and discussions matters. Grading was tough. Extremely not friendly to non-native speakers especially if you are not confident with your English.

One of the most frustrating professors I've ever had to deal with. The lectures are fine and engaging to some degree. But beyond that the setup for the course isn't great and Scott is obnoxiously hard on grading. The rubrics are sometimes unclear and you will miss points for things that will make you scratch your head.
Harsh grader

Overall a good professor. 
A lot of readings and the pop quizzes. 
First 3 Essays are reasonable. 
For presentation email him your idea and the ppt itself. 
For final paper talk to him in office hours and send him your first draft at least 5 days before it is due. 
I found Kantian argument easiest to make.

Mostly discussion-based, and if you put the effort to do the readings and try to participate, you're fine. He has pop-quizzes, but he gives the questions beforehand and they're open-note, so no surprises on their content. He is very helpful and skilled at leading good discussions. He also is very easy-going and has a good sense of humor.

As a senior majored in CSE, I believe that most professors here at OSU don't want you to fail, but Scott is obviously NOT that kind of professor. He asks tricky and absurd questions (and takes many pts off if you can't answer them) during your presentation and on your papers. His lecture is kinda enjoyable if you don't mind getting an awful grade.

Looking back on this class, I think it might have been the most interesting one I have taken at OSU. The grading was tougher than expected, but if you show you're invested in the class, your grade will improve. Sometimes I thought I was wasting my time in class, but looking back I wish I would have appreciated how interesting and original it was.

Scott was a very interesting teacher who did a good job at keeping the class engaged for the entire 1:20 class time. His grading was more harsh than expected with papers and presentations, and those were a significantly large portion of the grade. Overall a great teacher, just don't be lulled to sleep by the laid back lectures.

Very interesting class, and not too much work. However the grading on essays and presentations seems to be very subjective and tough, especially for a gen ed. Attendance is mandatory, and there are (very easy) pop quizzes on the daily readings. I'm not sure I would recommend this class over other options though.

Scott was a great professor. You must attend class but if you do and try, it is not hard to get an A. He has pop quizzes but as long as you do the reading and take notes, you will be able to do well. I attended office hours which was also super helpful to get feedback on the papers and ask questions about class material.
He is an approachable teacher and he teaches in way that today's students can understand. Although attendance is mandatory, everything else about the class is relatively easy.

Very enthusiastic and boisterous teacher. That helped keep class interesting while the material wasn't. He assigns a very easy 1200 word paper. Midterm was fair and easy.  Missing classes kills your grade. Don't skip. Does have pop quizzes based on discussion board and hw readings. Nice guy, approachable if you have questions or need help

This class was so easy and required little work, but it was super enjoyable and so interesting. Not a lot of homework, just weekly readings. Definitely take this for an easy gened and great professor.
Was a really fun class to go to and was very interesting
Clear teaching style.  Considers viewpoints of lots of people.  Charming.  Intelligent.  Logical.  Yes, would take classes from this professor again.  Always.

Best GE class I have taken so far. All of the topics are interesting. However, lectures can be overwhelming with the amount of stuff he takes notes on. Tests are easy and you can bring a cheat sheet. You have to write an essay using one of the topics and connect it with the thing that you are interested in but you can use AI to help you.

Professor Brown is an engaging and passionate teacher who makes this philosophy class super enjoyable. Easy grading, open-note quizzes, and minimal work - plus Unstuckstudy was a huge help for study prep!

Although I took this class for a GE and I don't care much for the subject, Dr. Brown had some of the most interesting lectures I have ever attended. He explained everything really well and is the easiest grader I have ever come across. I would recommend this course for anyone who needs a GE requirement.

Doc Brown loves to teach his material, he definitely isn't a professor who just reads off a slideshow. I didn't have much interest in philosophy ( I still don't)- but he just made it interesting and made me want to learn about it. Awesome professor, definitely recommend.

Classes are fun and interesting, lectures + discussion. There was a large group project component in my class (Global Flourishing) which I don't think was typical of his classes in general, but he was very laid back about things and it worked out really well for my group.
Interesting content and nice professor.  Clearly very knowledgable but does not have super structured lectures. Easy A if you attend class.

Very easy and interesting class. Takes attendance. Weekly reflections (≥3 sentences). Weekly homework: 1-2 readings and ≥3 annotations per reading. Only 2 exams (5 FRQs, 1 AI-assisted essay, and a note sheet). Dr. Brown is very passionate and lectures were engaging. Class highlights besides content: tea ceremony and temple visit. Highly recommend!!
Professor Brown is a funny and witty professor, he is clearly great at what he does and loves to teach his material. Class was easy to understand and material was always clarified.

Would 10000% recommend professor brown. Any of his classes are probably amazing. Really interesting to listen to and an easy A. Do the homework and you'll be fine. One midterm and a final, you can use AI for both essays and have a cheat sheet for the 5 short FRQs. He makes philosophy interesting.

My favorite professor this year. He was hilarious and passionate about what he was teaching. There's not too much homework besides a few readings and a weekly reflection—but nothing difficult. The exams are 5 FRQs, but he does the notes for you, so you just need to go over those. On the last day of class, he has a tea ceremony with his Grandma.

Dr. Brown is incredibly engaging and funny. The readings aren't always interesting but his lectures on the readings are. There are two short AI-assisted papers and two exams with a note sheet. Very easy A. He takes attendance. Take his class for your GE!
Very nice.  Very kind.  Not arrogant.   Listens to all viewpoints.

I had Professor Brown for "Death Meaning Life" and enjoyed his class from the first day to the last. The class itself is straightforward with the formatting. You read and annotate a couple of pages before class, talk about what you read, and then have a midterm and final on it. Great and engaging class overall. Amazing and caring professor!
Very inspirational and genuinely excited to teach. Wants to have dialogue with his students and welcomes questions and debate.
He made lectures interesting, even if the topic wasn't. He cares about his students and tries to do right by them. Almost no exams but the exams are very manageable.

He runs class well, but it is reading heavy with annotations every week. Attendance is taken each lecture, but he makes it really interesting each week. The only flaw in class is that he makes you take written notes while he types for the whole lecture, and it's impossible to keep up. Only 2 tests which you get cheat sheets for and are super easy.

Dr. Brown is hands down my favorite professor at OSU. I specifically took this class so I could have him as a professor again. The class itself is engaging, and requires deep thought. Just because Dr. Brown grades nicely does not mean the content is easy, as it is still requires hard work to understand the complex concepts.

Dr. Brown is very funny and is also very good at teaching his content and getting you to think (which is like the whole point of philosophy). Two pretty big papers, but you are encouraged to use AI to help you write, you just can't copy the whole thing from AI. The content is deeply interesting and academically enriching.

Dr. Brown is a fantastic professor! You can tell that he is super passionate about the subject he teaches. His lectures are thought-provoking, engaging, and often involving real-world events. The majority of your grade consists of two research papers with topics of your choice. Super chill and fun- I would 100% take a class with him again!

I LOVED THIS PROFESSOR! Attendance is mandatory, but I would go either way. His lectures are so engaging and fun, his heart is in his work. Only complaint is that assignments were randomly posted so I missed a few, but they are usually 1-2 points each and very easy. If you check Carmen twice a week you'll be fine.
He is absolutely the best!

Dr. Brown is an amazing and caring professor! Each of his lectures are very enlightening and his class has changed my opinions on so many different things. He is so caring to all of his students and is a very flexible professor. He will also make you believe in aliens.

Amazing and hilarious guy. I thought a philosophy class was going to be extremely boring and paper heavy, but not with him. There are a few quizzes, but it's open note so they're super easy. The reflections are also super easy. No exams, just an 800 word takeaway portfolio at the end which also isn't that hard. Take him if you need your GE!!!
Best and one of the easiest professors in the philosophy department. Come out every lecture with a different perspective. Very funny guy too

Easy grading and overall fun lectures. His easy grading takes away the pressure, and you can actually just enjoy learning the material he gives. He does a great job of explaining complex philosophies and makes it a fun process by cracking jokes and being retable.

I'd recommend Steven for your GE classes. His classes aren't much work, just show up and you will do well. He likes to talk about current events and compare it to class content which makes his class entertaining.

VERY FUNNY GUY

going to lectures is mandatory but it's worth it dude he's so funny with his tangents

and you may be thinking "oh isn't going off on tangents bad?"

fret not my philosopher friend these tangents are integral to the experience

very sad to be done with this class cause i love attending the lectures

Professor Brown was an elite professor, really funny person who made this class interesting and fun to learn. really wants his students to learn and cares about them, workload was low with weekly readings, quizzes were open note and untimed pretty easy, overall a really good class and professor brown is a goat

I love Prof. Brown. Take his class (PHILOS 2120) if you want a fun and easy GE. He is an incredible lecturer, makes students laugh every class, and clearly passionate about his work. Just be careful with attendance because he takes attendance twice every class and it is a decent part of the grade.
Brown is an excellent public speaker, and he knows how to keep his audience engaged. Very laid back and chill. One the easiest classes I've ever taken.

Such a cool guy. Very open about his personality and lets it shine through his work, genuinely cares, and is pretty funny. Not really any grades in this class, I didn't even take notes, I'd just sit and listen!

Just amazing. Super willing to talk about cool stuff outside of class. He cares a lot about the subject matter and helping students with it. One of the coolest dudes of all time. Also likes great music. Based guy.

Great guy who knows his stuff and wants the best for the students. He teaches you a lot about life during this class and no matter what your opinions are, you will learn at least something valuable in this course.

If you get the chance, take a class with Dr. Brown. He is one of the most charismatic, most enthralling professors I've ever had the pleasure to take a course with. I literally created this account to let people know how badly they need to take a course with him. 100/10 would recommend. Life changing lecturer.

Professor Brown is awesome. This class is very easy and you can get an A easily by just showing up (attendance is 20%, can miss 3) and doing simple assignments. Many people just showed up at the end of class and got the tophat code but I thought that was crappy and that his lectures were very much worth showing up and listening to. Great professor.

Overall great class but the randomness of assignments threw me off, he randomly says that there is a reading due next Thursday. There is not an overwhelming amount of reading but there is some required writing. Overall great class and professor.

My favorite professor at OSU! He is hilarious during lectures and he really gives out good information. Homework is light and stress free and he makes the notes for you so you don't have to. Would definitely take a other class with him if I have the chance.

This class was really interesting, and there were only a couple of easy quizzes, and like 3 papers. He makes class fun and has good discussions. I was worried about taking this class because it sounded boring but his personality makes lectures interesting and keeps your attention really well
Best porf ever.

His lectures were one of the best I have ever been to. This course is amazing, its extremely engaging. I love that Professor Brown does not have a fixed syllabus and let's the class take it's own path based on extremely engaging discussions. He is also a very jolly and funny person, so it's a great class to attend first thing in the morning.
He's Awesome

This class is ENTIRELY lecture based with no imagery to look at while the lecture is happening... if you're not an auditory learner, do not take this class. It is very easy to get by, but I did not retain any of the information. I had 250 in my class and 80% of them were doing something else on their computer -- it's one of those types of classes.

Dr. Brown is an amazing professor. You can tell from his lectures just how knowledgable and intelligent he is. He conveys the information in a way that keeps you actively listening, retaining the info, and enjoying the lecture as well.
Very smart man and an excellent instructor, I looked forward to class.
Two words: great professor.

Asian Philos was great, super interesting! No need to take notes or get a textbook bc the notes are shared w/you on a doc. Quizzes are all easy based on notes and readings are easy too! Overall you can get an A doing the bare minimum (I did) and lecture is very interesting. The easy grading allowed me to pay attn and actually learn w/o worrying!
An interesting professor! He has a clear mind and his philosophy classes are not boring! I would like to take his other classes!
An amazing course and professor. I highly recommend this course. Its easy A if you show up to class and stay up to date on the assignments.

What a lovely guy. As long as you have a brain, you will get an A. NO exams. Handful of quizzes that you get multiple attempts on. 3 papers. Reading reflections for participation points. Literally most of the points are participation points. Take this class. Even if you aren't interested in philosophy. I'm not, but he managed to make it interesting

Absolutely loved his class! I took this class as well as Death and The Meaning of Life at the same time. Loved it! He really motivated me to learn more about philosophy! He is very funny, cares about his students and is so funny. If you are looking for a fun GE course or want to learn some basic philosophy, take his courses!

Easy class, pay attention write notes/use his for the quizzes and exams. the answers can almost always be found in the notes. There is only 2 exams and 2 essays. I would highly recommend going to office hours for the essays as they give good feedback on your essay before you turn it in.  Overall you NEED NOTES i took this online so he gave us his
Really funny. Not a lot of grades but everything is open note. His online lectures werent mandatory and we could rewatch later on. I enjoyed his class.

he is a great philosophy teacher, very passionate and caring of his students! dont take this class if you dont like to think. he encourages us to question and think in his classes. classes are structured nice. a few quizzes,one for each topic, only top 5 count for grade.2 exams and paper +EC opportunity. class require work and critical thinking!

Would not recommend to take class as a GE. While the quizzes are very straight forward, the exams are a big part of your grade and there are only two of them. I did not regularly attend lectures, but know many people who did and got a worse grade than me.

Don't take this class if you don't think like a philosophy teacher. His quizzes are so difficult because he makes every question have what seems like more than one answer, and there aren't enough points to make up for the fact that you may miss one trick question on every assignment. He won't tell you when anything is due until a week before.
Good professor. There are 2 exams that 25% so its test heavy but they are not that many questions and he gives you plenty of time. Loved this class.

Professor Brown is super funny and his lectures are really interesting. He takes notes during the class so you dont have to attend lecture to pass which is nice. There arnt many grades in the class tho so be careful!

I love this man. He's very type-B with pretty much everything in his class. Short and easy quizzes, very few assignments, and a pretty chill schedule. His lectures are always incredibly enjoyable and they were always the highlights of my week. He also has an ongoing public document for all lecture notes so we didn't need to take any. 10/10 class

This is the type of professor i wish all GE's had. He uses a loose schedule (but always gives an advance on quizzes/exams to study) and the class has a loose structure. This means the classes are always so much more interesting because he allows students to question the content and will dive deep into philosophical questions.

Dr. Brown is definitely passionate about philosophy, but often times gets off topic during lectures. At the beginning of class they said only participation in recitation was required, but then I was deducted credit for missing some lectures. Also, for the papers, they take off silly points. Overall, not a bad class.
great professor, very sweet and caring. helps a lot and really cares about his students success

He is an awesome teacher and makes the class reasonable but he says it is an overtly easy A and that is not true, as he graded papers and exams relatively harshly. The topics of the class were interesting and taught to us well, I just wish he made a better attempt to fulfill his promise of the class being an easy A if you just do the basics...
Chill and Laid Back Teacher
If you ever have to take Philosophy class at OSU, you should take him for sure. Lectures are great and interesting. He is an easy smart guy!

Professor Brown is amazing. He really knows the subject that he is teaching and his lectures are very interesting. You get a 1% extra credit by attending the lectures. There is no homework at all. Just go to the lectures and be prepared for the short answer exams and you will get an A.

Professor Brown is AMAZING! His lectures are hilarious and he is very good at explaining the material. His quizzes and tests are pretty easy and you get a cheat sheet for exams. His class was amazing; it was the only class I didn't dread going to and that I was actually excited to attend that semester. Would defintely take him again!

Dr. Brown is hilarious and passionate about the material. We talked about Star Wars a lot and watched a decent amount of videos, so if that's not your thing this professor might not be a great fit. You don't really have to study (you get a sheet of notes for exams), he gives extra credit, and the work load is minimal, so great for a GE class.

Awesome, funny professor! It is surprising how much energy he has every single class. The material is super interesting, and he tries a lot to make obscure philosophical concepts easy to swallow. Few assignments, and they're all pretty easy.

Dr. Brown is a great teacher and I highly enjoyed the class I took with him. Lectures are pretty much required as that is where you receive the notes and information that is on the quiz. The only homework consisted of the occasional online quiz and reading some short papers before class. His lectures are super informative.

Dr. Brown is super passionate about philosophy, has good jokes and explains complex topics in easy to understand ways. He teaches the class like a GE should be taught with minimal homework. If you pay attention in class you'll do well.
Super super nice guy, very fun professor. Slacked off and thought it was gonna be a very easy A and it shouldve been. Didn't study at all on the final and it hurt me.

Probably my favorite prof at OSU. He is great and teaches a general education class like it should be. It is interesting and stress free, yet still provides you with a great understanding of the subjects. You come out learning something new. If you show up to class you will do well, no curveballs are thrown on the tests and you get a cheat sheet.

Nice guy and his lectures are funny but his lectures can be confusing and it can be hard to decipher what information you actually need. The class is graded on so few things that it is a bit stressful, but as long as you actually come to class you should be fine.
Dude is hilarious. Great prof that makes class fun to come to.

I took this for a GE credit and he was a great professor. The tests and one mandatory paper were easy. He gave several opportunities to raise your grade. He makes a real effort to make lectures interesting. The side rants were entertaining and the content was never really difficult. If you show up to lecture, you're guaranteed to do well.

Don't take if looking for an easy A. Not a lot of work, but the papers and exam essays are graded harshly with weird symbols no one understands with no criteria or rubric given to be graded so harshly. Grades not recorded online until the class begged him to do so. Gives little feedback and never answers questions clearly. Very hard to raise grade.

There are few ways to get points making it hard to bring your grade up or get a good one because he is a tough grader. You can take the final and write another paper to bring up your grade. Rambles in class making it hard to understand when the information is important enough to write down and what will be on the exams & Atten. basically mandatory

Dr. Brown is a phenomenal teacher. He is clear and concise about what you need to know, and makes every day entertaining. Midterms and the paper are easy, and he gives optional quizzes and an extra paper to help with grades - these aren't counted against you if they hurt your grade. He also gives extra credit for participation/attendance. Take him
He's a funny guy; his class isn't necessarily the most fun,  but he makes it pretty entertaining most days.

Prof Brown has an incredible way of teaching even complex concepts in a way that an average person can not only understand but contribute to the conversation. He values your opinion and encourages you to think for yourself.
Good lecturer. Doesn't personally grade tests or papers, passes them along to other graders

SO, I got a B on an exam I studied so hard for. Like I had a study guide and it was pointless. Homeboy does the most when he is teaching. Like he gives long examples that have NOTHING to do with the subject.

Terrible professor who makes this GE so challenging. Exams are open notes but your points get chipped away so fast. Papers are harshly graded on, and my second optional paper was not even graded when the final grade came out. A lot of extra credits but those pull up grade like 1%. If you are taking Phil 2120 avoid this guy. Tried hard but only B+.

I loved this class so much! I took ethics initially to satisfy a GE but I fell in love with philosophy and am now minoring in it.  Professor Brown has become one of my favorite people in the entire world.  He is funny and his lectures are my favorite part of the day.  Take this class- it won't disappoint.

Dr. Brown makes class entertaining, tying current events and stereotypes into his everyday lessons. He relies a lot on class discussion, so this is very interesting if you care at all about the subjects. He has quizzes every few weeks, but he only puts them in if they helps your grade, so it's an easy GE. Attendance is optional, but is extra credit

I expect very little out of GE courses like PHILOS1300. That being said I looked forward to coming to class because I knew that Steven made the material interesting. He makes getting an A a very achievable goal, simply show up to class and take some notes. That isn't a lot to ask for when you spend most of the class discussing Star Wars.

By far my favorite professor at OSU. I took 2 courses from him and looked forward to each and every class. I have always loved philosophy, but friends I have made in his classes has zero interest in philosophical debates before his class, yet still thoroughly enjoyed his lectures and learned quite a lot. I would recommend Dr. Brown to anyone!

Best classroom experience I've had at Ohio State! I came for the credit, I stayed for the captivating lectures, and I left with a new view on the world and the people around me. Steven Brown is simply amazing.
Fun class. It was his first time teaching it so he struggled at times. EZ gen ed.

My favorite teacher so far at Ohio State. He comes into class every day full of energy and coffee in hand. It was the only 8am I would ever take again. He makes possibly dull content entertaining. If you are looking for a fun, easy A class, take this. You will learn a lot about how/why we think the things we do.
Class was great
Asian Philosophies was the easiest class I've ever taken (cheat sheets allowed for exams that are already very simple, and only one short paper), and it was also interesting. Steven Brown is awesome.

Funny professor! Going to class is an enjoyable experience. Youll learn a lot about the philos as well as random tidbits about the world when he digresses:) Easy A Only 2 midterms which you will be allowed a cheat sheet for. I recommend this class to anyone as long as you do not get offended easily by controversial subjects. He won't sugarcoat

Funny professor! Going to class is an enjoyable experience. Youll learn a lot about the problems with art as well as random tidbits about the world when he digresses:) Easy A Only 2 midterms and 1 paper. you get a cheat on test. I recommend this class to anyone as long as you do not get offended easily by controversial subjects. He won't sugarcoat

Mr. Brown is the best teacher I have ever had. He explains readings very clearly and is genuinely interested in helping. He does not talk down to you, which especially made me feel more open to talk to him when I was having issues or questions on a topic. Only 2 quizzes and 2 exams, no homework. You'll actually learn and have fun!
Best prof I ever had at OSU. Take one of his classes, you'll actually learn and and you'll love him.

Been at OSU for 3 years, and this guy is the best lecturer I've ever had. Clear, hilarious, and great at making the points he wants you to know. First time I've ever literally looked forward to going to a lecture every day. Take any class you can with this guy, he's fantastic!

I had Dr. Brown for Ethics and Intro to Philosophy and am so glad I had the opportunity to take classes with him. He is very energetic and extremely fair. If you need help he is always right there. He has to be Ohio States finest. If you make an effort to care about the class he makes an effort to care about your grade. He likes to maximize the min

He is the man. Lectures are clear as a whistle. Exams are essentially your notes, so take good notes of what he says and writes on the board. Taking his class was like a breath of fresh air. He's hilarious, understands the material well, and makes the student really enjoy philosophy. Would take again.

I had this class as an 8am and I can honestly say it was worth getting up to come to. Professor Brown was so energetic, passionate, and hilarious. Despite his refreshing spastic-ness, he is extremely knowledgeable and very clear when explaining concepts. The only two grades were the midterm and the final, though, so take good notes.

Great professor. Intelligent, passionate, knowledgeable, and can display the concepts to others with ease. Very active and upbeat, infectious energy. Makes you want to learn and understand. Allows for discussion and debate in a civil classroom setting without invalidating anyones opinions. Does not introduce his own beliefs in teaching. overall A++

Steven Brown is amazing. He is so funny and entertaining. I legitimately enjoyed coming to class not to mention I learned so much. Because of this class, I want to minor in philosophy. He explains difficult concepts with ease and his class(es) will be stay with you and change your perspective on life.  Also, his class is pretty easy.
Nice man.  Great examples.  Lots of humor.  Most enjoyable.  Excellent teaching abilities.  He should go far.  10/10

Very easy class. Just go to class and take notes. You'll be fine on both the exams and quiz. Only 2 exams and not CUM, 10 quiz which is very easy. He's quite interesting and laugh every joke himself says...

So extremely offbeat but in a good way, and gives us essay questions/key terms ahead of time (for midterm), PLUS one full cheat sheet able to be used on all exams. Quizzes are open note but timed on Carmen.
Steven has a good sense of humor. He's very intelligent and knowledgable. Quality professor.

He was by far on of the best professors I've ever had here. He was funny and kept all the material interesting. His teaching style kept me interested in the class and his ability to be personal in a large classroom was astounding.

There couldn't be a better philosophy teacher, hands down. This was a Saturday class, so things were a bit different than they might normally be, but daily quizzes not hard at all if you take notes and read. Papers and exams slightly harder. Amazing teacher. In 5 years at OSU, I learned more in this class than in any other. Take his class. Amazing.

Really was a fun teacher, I sat in the back all quarter, bad idea, I suggest you be actively engaged in the class. Definitely do the readings, his quizzes don't require reading (open notes) but your essays will suffer if you don't, trust me. Learn as much from him as you can!

This guy is great. Friendly, funny, and you can tell he loves what he does. You're guaranteed at least a B with bare minimum effort. Learned a lot from this guy. If youre a girl whose into dorky guys, you'll love this guy. Just saying... haha
He is great. He makes class fun and interesting. Extremely friendly and nice. He is one of the best professors I have ever had!

Lectures were interesting and he was quite funny. Don't sit in the back, he mumbles quite a bit. No real book, but excerpts of philophers writings-MUST READ THESE. His tests were cake, so long as you filled out the study guide and went to class. Was very unbiased with views on religion; which is how it should be in this sort of class.

Could be a very dry class, Social/moral problems in US, but he was enthusiastic and engaging. I just remember him writing/drawing on the board figuring out the issues, calling on people and spinning around shouting Yes! with each point, often dawdling back and forth wrestling with the lesser "ehhhhh" kind of remarks trying to make them fit. Great!
Awesome professor
Best. Teacher. Ever. Hilarious, great discussions, and fair. This guy's gonna go on to be a great prof when he gets his Ph.D.

Steven is a great teacher even though some of the material is rather confusing, and at times boring. We had daily quizzes over our reading, which actually helped to keep us current with the reading assingments. His exams are moderately easy and he gives you good study tips. Overall, he's really nice and nerdy funny!

The topics were more interesting than I thought they would be.  Papers are pretty easy to write as long as you read and go to class for discussions.  You could also submit drafts that he would grade and return for you to fix.
Very cool and funny guy.  Made a very very very very boring class at least tolerable.  Responds to emails pretty quickly and is an all around nice guy.
Very slow at responding to emails.

Straight forward expectations from the get-go. Readings due before pretty much every class (20-30 pages per class period). Assignments self-paced, not many outside of participation (if so, mainly papers). He's passionate in class and at office hours. Flexible with due dates. A little socially awkward at times. Good vibes overall.
Take Philos 1332  with him he makes it easy.
One of the best professors in the Philosophy department. Dont need to say anything else
Awesome professor, would love to have him again.

Amazing professor. Gives very clear lectures and he explains the content in a way where you understand. He is very clear on the grading material. Exams are super easy if you showed up to class and did the readings, there are no surprises or tricks questions. DEFINITELY TAKE HIM!!! Attendance is mandatory so if you want that A show up and try.

My favorite professor so far. Super chill guy and explains things so well. You never feel afraid to ask questions or for him to elaborate. Went to office hours to ask questions about test and got points back. Rlly cares about the students!!

It's a no brainer to take Philos 1332 with this guy. He makes the content likeable and provides a very good environment for discussion. Exams super easy, 4 short writing assignments you can do at any time of the year. Also learned a lot from this class and was not difficult at all

If you're taking 1332, take Olson. He is very understanding and has very few assignments. The ones he does assign he helps out greatly. The exams were easy if you were present in class. Just show up to class, put some effort into the assignments, and study a little for the exams and this is an easy A. Plus, Olson is a cool guy who lectures well.

He is a great professor! You definitely need to know and study the material to pass the tests, but everything on them was talked about during class and mentioned in the study guides. So glad I took this class with him he made the lectures interesting and I have zero complaints.

Really chill guy, attendance isnt mandatory but lectures are usually fun (Socratic method for most lectures). There is a lot of assigned reading but its easy to get by without doing most of it. Interesting topics that challenge beliefs.

Donny is so funny! You can tell he genuinely loves what he teaches. He is so sweet to us students and cares about each one of us, he even has coffee gatherings with us! If any other teacher taught this class I would not be interested, but he keeps me engaged with the way he describes court cases.

Donny is a great, caring professor. He actively tries to create an inclusive, open discussion in his class. Donny makes himself extremely available to help, especially for assistance on the class's three graded papers. Take his class, especially if you are interested in law school. (he will write a letter of recommendation if you receive an A)
Donny is a great professor. His philosophy of the law class was engaging. He's definitely not the easiest professor, but he's very fair and gives a lot of grace.

Loved the idea of this class already, and Jacob made it super fun/interesting. The lectures are interesting, and make sense, and he really encourages questions, and is warm and thoughtful in how he answers them. It makes the learning environment really easy to get into. If I enroll in a phil class again, I'd keep an eye out for what he's teaching.
Jacob is a great instructor. He is very nice and good at explaining things. This was my first philosophy class, but he made the information very accessible.

Jacob loves philosophy and teaching, and it showed. He explains things clearly, with fun examples. Review guides for quizzes were super helpful. I learned a lot and would definitely take more classes with him.

Jacob has made this class much more difficult through his own efforts. Not only is there are 30% in person quizzes without cheatsheet, but he even had a project that was 40% of the class. Other professors in the same course don't even have quizzes.

The structure of the course is very clear, however, far too much work for a GE course. Written grading was subjective and did not reflect all points of view. Take the class if it is required, otherwise find something easier that won't take up too much of your time. Post-tests were written super confusingly that it made some questions illegible.

Overall, good professor. He's very thorough about AI, which may unintentionally penalize you if you're naturally a good writer, so keep a record of timestamps when writing. Also, no matter how close you are to getting the next letter grade up at the end of the semester, forget about it as he doesn't believe in rounding grades.

He was very easy to contact and although there were a lot of assignments sometimes they were fairly easy to complete. Also allows to make up credit for the midterm which was nice. He is very big on COAM and will report anything that he thinks might be AI. His lectures were also simple and entertaining with his humor.

I loved his class! It seems like it will be a lot of work but I don't think it is, but I found the class very enjoyable! You usually have a quick reading, pre test (completion grade), discussion post (completion grade), and a post test. The pre-test and and post-test are the same questions and only like 8 questions. Great Professor and easy class!

not understanding: you cannot miss a class because of expensive flight prices or routine checkups/appointments, no technology, expects you to meet specific standards but does not teach how to, very nitpicky, comes off pretentious in both grading and class discussions, tbh would switch professors if ur interested in 2120
Well-spoken.  Knowledgeable.  Creative.  Knows his subject matter.  TA was nice.
Very good.
Too bad he's retired. He's a great professor, and I'm glad to have had him before then.

ummm I am not a philosophy major and just took it for a GEC but it ended up just as hard as my other classes. The concepts are too huge to understand if you're not a philos major. There should be other graded materials other than 2 midterms and a final. This class was very difficult for me as he was also very dry and boring.

I loved this class. If you arent really interested in the topic, it would probably be difficult to stay motivated. For me however, I was totally interested in the information, so that class was great for me.
I didn't like Pappas at all. I thought that his grading was really hard, I didn't like my TA either.

I loved Pappas. I also liked that he is well known in the Philosophy world. My brother-in-law was very excited to learn who my teacher was, as he has a master's in Philosophy. Easy class, just read. No need to really study. A lot of it is common sense.
He's a good guy and his examples are helpful, but things get a bit boring as the quarter draws on.  Midterms are pretty easy.

Pappas is very boring to listen to in lecture but the material is interesting....lectures get really dry as the quarter goes on...the bad this is that the final is 50% of your grade!!! so dont mess up on that.  Overall though he isnt too bad he give out the notes online but seems to promote his book too much.
poor supervision of ta's

this was a really great class. but you have to go to lecture and take awesome notes. study as you go along too or it becomes way too hard to grasp the concepts at the last minute it you procrastinate. brian taylor-highly recommend him as a TA, he was awesome!!

Nice teacher.  Good in explaining, but at first the principles are hazy until he brings them down to earth -- such as his examples.  A good person, however, and I am happy to see that he has become chair of his department.  Congrats to Dr. Pappas.
sooooo easy
No Comments

This guy is possibly the worst and most boring teacher I have had and probably will have in my life.  Plus he tsrangley resembles John Lithgough who played Dick on third rock from the sun.  He played a professor on the show, coincidence, I think not.
No Comments
Has lots of information.  Interesting concepts.  Great thinker, and tries to explain as he goes.  Better watch out that he gets dry & boring.
A very tough thinker. A really dedicated teacher. Also quite handsome!
He is the greatest to ever do it.

Loved the grading scale, he set it up where there was plenty of 'extra' points to receive if you missed or did bad on other assignments, but most assignments are just graded on completion and participation.

Prof Papenhausen is the GOAT. He is very fun, and makes sure to stay pretty neutral on things. The class is mostly group discussion, and he regulates it well. He kinda looks like a gnome but in a funny cute way. Love his class, great prof, highly reccomend
Vaughn is Him.

Vaughn is the biggest sweetheart in the world. He is a very caring professor and he tries to learn everyone in his class by name. He is not very tough with grading and the class is mostly about participation and putting in effort.

Dr. Woods was very kind to students and made the expectations for the course very clear. He didn't let class drag on and once he finished his lecture he'd end class early. Overall he was a great instructor and all assignments/test are online.

Class was completely online. He was very organized and had everything ready. It was usually 2 homework's and a quiz every week. It was hard to bring your grade back up without tests because things weren't waited as heavy. However, the material is fairly easy to grasp because he gives a lot of examples and quizzes will match 
what you have learned
Logic and Legal Reasoning is the class to take to fill the math credit for the GE. Professor Woods makes the course easy to understand and is very easy to reach if you have questions.
I took one of his classes at OWU, probably one of the best philosophy classes I've ever taken!

Dr. Woods is an amazing lecturer and I recommend attending class for the fun conversation-style lectures (even though they aren't necessarily required for a good grade). Class stays true to the syllabus and exams are fair, so it is very reasonable to earn an A as long as you put in reasonable effort and don't miss deadlines. Very interesting course
The lectures (although not mandatory) are fun in general to attend. His teaching style was more conversational than straight up material which I enjoyed. I enjoyed this class.

PHILOS 1332 consisted of 20 easy discussion posts, 8 quizzes, 2 group projects, a midterm and final which both involve short and long essays. Generally easy course if you keep up and do the readings. It won't be a super easy A but highly possible to get an A if you put in a little effort. Overall a pretty great professor.

Many discussion posts, but they are graded super easy. Two group projects, one of which is a 55min long presentation. Syllabus didn't say exams were closed/open note, but quizzes were always open. Instructor waited until the week of the exam to inform us that it would be closed note instead. Expected a little more consideration from an ethics prof.

The online nature of this course made it very dull at times. The subject matter is closer to math than anything philosophical in the traditional sense. First C I ever got, I flat-out struggled with coursework several times during the semester. Very willing to answer any questions students had. Wish the course was online, but the pandemic happened.

He is always there for his students and is always willing to help and have extra review session for anyone needing it. He is always easily available and is lecture are really interesting. He is laid back and a pretty easy grader. He loves philosophy and he is great at conversations. He never shows bias about a topic and he is the best teacher ever.

Intro to Logic, I took online with Evan. He give great lecutures to go along with the textbook reading. If you have a question just email him, he reply back quickly and helps you understand the material you may be stuck on.

Professor Woods is pretty laid back. He's available for help, all you have to do is ask. The work can be complex (sometimes) but if you read the textbook and lectures, it's an easy A. Just a heads up, if you take this course online, the final exam is still in person.
Great professor, knows his subject area, clearly communicates expectations for assignments and exams. Lot's of reading, reading responses, etc.

He kept it real, and interacted with the students if the students interacted with him. He uses the chalkboard and hand writes terms and notes, that you need to know. And goes over content to the fullest extent. Some might find the old fashioned way boring, but it was really helpful! If you're into math, logic and philosophy, I recommend him!

Do Not Take This Class. Was taken as a GE Class but ended up being my hardest class by far, taught and graded like a 4000-level class. Teacher is an extremely hard grader on papers that account for 50% of the grade. There is also an immense amount of reading involved for the class, anywhere from 10-30 pages per week.

Sure, he grades hard, but this is because he really cares about reading comprehension & understanding the text. If you're nervous about paper grades meet with him as much as possible more than a week before the paper is due. If you try, he can tell.

This is my second time taking a class with Alex. He is an amazing professor who truly cares about his students. Lectures and class content in general are incredibly engaging. If you engage in class discussion and dig deep into the readings, his class is incredibly rewarding on a personal and academic level.

He was by far the most engaging philosophy instructor I've had! Topics were really well discussed and engaging, and if you engage with the readings in class, the papers are not as bad as they sound. Would definitely take another class just to hear more of his analysis of certain theories!
Grade is based on four papers that are graded extremely harsh. Feedback is unclear and not helpful. Do not recommend!!

I have not yet completed this course however, he sucks. This is a 2000-level course but he grades it as if it were a 4000-level course. He taught at Boulder and the reviews were extremely accurate. Unclear in his feedback and expectations, doesn't offer how to help you improve. Extremely harsh grader, do not recommend.

Dr. Ashton was a wonderful professor! Her videos and readings were great and her assignments were very fair! Videos instead of exams were a nice take and fun, and quizzes were very reasonable, being open-note. It's a shame students tried to use ChatGPT, however, evident by announcements. Great class and pretty easy!

Professor Ashton was extremely kind, understanding, gave clear feedback, and helped us understand the material. The beginning of the course was stressful and she made things less stressful and she had faith in me. She has an amazing sense of humor as well which made the class fun.

Zoe was not my favorite instructor in the beginning because of a few grade misunderstandings and miscommunications but she will recognize when youre putting the work in and will try to bump up your grade. She offers many extra credit assignments if she realizes the class is struggling. Lots of writing assignments, but better than math.

Professor Ashton is amazing! She will adapt the class if needed and truly wants you to succeed. There is no midterm/final but instead small quizzes and written assignments throughout the year to make your grade. She is extremely helpful and makes the class interesting. I highly recommend taking this for Data Analysis GE to avoid math!
His class was the worst 3 hours of my week consistently avoid taking him if you can. Participation mattered too much and he was very condescending in how he did discussions.

This professor is a nice man but he relies on class participation for a grade even though the discussions can get confusing in lecture. It gets boring and some of the conversations seem like they're all over the place. Grades can be easy as there's weekly assignments but the exams need good preparation to get a good grade.

2340 as a class includes interesting content, however Professor Lin makes it mind-numbingly boring. His lectures are monotone and he challenges every comment made by every student. Frequently you'd look around and see people watching Netflix or playing games rather than listening. Avoid ;)

This class is really what you choose to make of it. If the class participates in group discussion it is really interesting and very fun but it is boring when they don't. Lots of reading but you can get away with skimming. Tests are easy as long as you elaborate.

Most of the grade is based off one paper which is a lot of pressure. Is passionate about teaching but I found it very heavy and uninteresting. Think the class would be great to take in person rather than online.

He was fine. Nothing super bad, nothing super great. There was way too much reading though. I honestly only ever skimmed like on chapter of one of the books so I wouldnt buy them. You can definitely pass doing the bare minimum. I didnt mind the professor as much as I minded the class.

Three papers and weekly blog posts. As long as you ask him to proofread your papers, you are basically guaranteed an A in the course. He likes to hear himself talk, so class is usually an hour of him talking about the things we read about. Overall, an okay teacher. Nothing good, nothing bad. Just fine.

Class can be boring and it is tough to focus in lecture so bring caffeine!! Some topics are interesting, however if you don't like open ended questions this is not the class for you. I did the readings first half and they are just more confusing, so I would not say they are needed. Definitely find a study group to talk through tough concepts!!!

It is clear that Professor Lin is very well-versed in the material, and he wants to have a discussion with his students about it; however, it's not always easy put forth an idea because he may or may not rip it apart. I found it hard to stay awake during his lectures. Weekly blog posts and readings, three papers, no final.

Professor Lin is one of my favorite professors. He talks very clearly and truly cares that each student gets a chance to ask a question. He genuinely cares if you understand the content, because philosophy is hard. This is a great course and as long as you pay some attention, you should do fine. You get a chance to talk about some interesting stuff

His teaching skills are excellent, but I'd say his people skills could use some work. A bit too serious about everything and lectures intensely. So he can seem fairly intimidating. He's intent on doing a good job though. He wants to have discussion, he wants to engage, he wants you to learn. But don't expect him to be be very warm or inspirational.

Content could get a bit nuanced at times, but good professor and generally easy class. The midterm was MC and essays, but the final was just a bunch of essays, and it was definitely easier that way. Weekly quizzes were fine, and two short papers were graded pretty easily. Class content definitely skews one way, but is interesting nonetheless.

Very interesting class and does a good job engaging students in discussions. Chooses interesting things for us to read and gives great feedback for papers and reading responses. Very chill prof who is always willing to talk and explore different perspectives.

This class ran like a high school class, for better or for worse. For an intro class, I liked that. He is a fantastic teacher. He makes everything very clear and sets everyone up for success. Every class, you thoroughly review what you talked about last class. Does get a bit boring at times. However, the material is accessible and you learn a lot.
Wonderful professor.  I miss her.  She left OSU and there are not much left in terms of bioethics courses that make premeds succeed in the med school application process.

Dr. Nakano was truly knowledgeable and personable, and this  was easily the best course I have ever taken, and it contained far more than lectures! I doubt whether the person who posted above is a real student, as all students who took this class were either science-major or polsci major. No philosophy major was there!

Dr. Nakano is BRILLIANT, but you wouldn't know because of how she lectures (very hard to understand). But outside of class she's very helpful and eager to expose students to bioethics. This class was very easy with your grade based on short essays and a presentation. As a philosophy major though, I wished there was more "scholarly content."

Lots and lots of reading--3 to 4 articles per week. There's also 3 essays worth 15%, 20%, and 30% of your grade. Although an interesting class, the amount of work couldn't justify that the class was just a gened.  Unless you're REALLY into philosophy, don't take this class.

By the time the semester ended, I still only had 15% of my grade for this class, so there was no way to figure out how I would do in the class until it was over. Very shaky grading criteria, and I've never had a professor who grades slower.
Solid professor. He's very willing to work with you if you need help. A little too "textbook heavy", most lectures he is just going over what is being described in the book.

He's very slow at grading papers but he gives extremely detailed, constructive feedback. I'm a philosophy major who wasn't into the predominantly analytic readings, but the class wasn't bad overall. That being said, it has been nearly a month and he still hasn't graded our final papers, so I'm still awaiting my final grade.

This is one of the most interesting classes I've taken at OSU. Martin is very clear and thorough in his lectures. He is slow with grading but gives great feedback and shows a true interest in helping students. He is also very funny.

Turner is a humorous, interesting instructor, as well as a useful and friendly one.  He cares for the students' education and especially in their progress of learning material. He is mostly thorough and clear in his lectures-- though sometimes wordy, especially in messages. Still, I don't have much a complaint.   Would definitely recommend.
I do not recommend taking this class just to fulfill a GE

Participation is a major part of the grade in this class. I did not miss a single lecture, but 5.5% of my final grade was deducted for not raising my hand enough in class (which admittedly I only did about 5 times during class). This made the difference between an A and an A- for me. This class was also a little boring and dry.

Wesley is hands down the best professor I've ever had!! He makes all of his lectures very interesting and doesn't make you feel bad about asking questions. I would definitely take him every semester if i could. Only 3 exams which are written but not too hard and 4 response papers but he makes it as easy as possible for you to do!

Awesome professor! Never would have thought I would enjoy philosophy before taking his class. He's one of those who is very clear and makes you actually think. Very personable. Tests are easy if you take good notes. Highly recommend taking him!

I had professor Cray for Asian Philosophy & it is a straight lecture but he makes it very entertaining, clear & an overall easy class if you attend every day. Not to mention hes so laid back, chill, funny AND extremely insightful so he comes off quite attractive.
Wes is the coolest guy I know. You should check out how his facial hair changes throughout the course.
Philosophy 270 (religion) was a great course - largely thanks to the professors. Wesley is a great philosopher and a funny guy. He's very knowledgeable. Take a course by him if you get the chance.
Great instructor. Doesn't use a book or post notes on carmen. Therefore, attendance is pretty much a necessity.
Uses standard grading scheme. Exams are pretty fair. Good instructor in general. Piercings/tattoos.
Similes are irreplaceable in the process of understanding philosophical theories, and Wes' are very clear and easy to understand. Great class, great professors. (taught alongside Prof. S. Bown)

He's an overall great instructor (clear, helpful, dedicated, knowledgeable), but as a person, he's somewhat pretentious. While he's an extremely intelligent man, he definitely lacks humility and actively portrays an image of superiority over others (even his peer philosophers.) But, as an instructor, I would definitely recommend him.

Wesley is a great instructor. I've had him for two consecutive philosophy courses and both were taught extremely well. His lectures are clear and organized, and he makes the material easily comprehensible by providing an element of entertainment in the class. Great instructor, handsome (not that it matters), and I would definitely recommend him.

LOVED this class, it was stimulating and fun to go to. Attendance was not mandatory but it effected your grade if you missed too much.  The midterms and exams were over what was taught and required studying but it was not a pain to review the material. The effort you put in was definitely rewarded.

Wesley was an excellent professor for Philosophy. Clear instruction and genuinely cared about his students. Study, and you will do well on the exams. He had a bunch of funny stories and the class is more entertaining than you would think! Highly recommended and a real asset to Ohio State University.
Great teacher, extremely happy, extremely nice. Not interested in Phil 150 before the class, one of my best classes this quarter.

Wesley is a great teacher and an all around great guy. He has a good sense of humor and he makes the material interesting and comprehensible without assigning ridiculous amounts of work. As long as you go to class, you'll do well. I wish there were more teachers like him -- not to mention, he's pretty handsome too.

This guy is a great teacher, I am taking this class for the second time the first time I failed it because my teacher could not explain the material clearly. Wesley on the other hand, explains material clearly and he is VERY nice to look at. He is helpful and although I never needed appointments he makes it very clear that he is willing to help.

Wesley is cool guy. I'm not a huge fan of philosophy but taking the class wasn't torture. As long as you go to class and take good notes and ASK, I mean ask if you have any ?'s, and study unless you're gifted, you'll do fine on the exams. He wants to help students learn this stuff.

Wesley is a great teacher and a cool guy all around.  He uses a lot of analogies and examples to explain the material, and it isn?t really necessary to do the reading because he goes over everything in class.  His exams are fair and you?ll do well so long as you go to class. If you have any questions he is willing to help and is easy to approach.

Wesley is a really great teacher and just a cool guy all around.  He uses a lot of analogies and clever examples to explain the material, and you can tell he really knows his stuff.  It isn?t really necessary to do the reading because he goes over everything in class.  His exams are fair and you?ll do well so long as you go to class.  If you have a

wesley is a cool guy, just go to the lecture and take notes and youll never have to open the book, go to a few of his office hours if you want to clear things up, no homework just go to class and youll be in good shape, overall a good class to take
would recommend one of his classes
I liked this class, but I had to go to get a good grade.
No Comments
Wesley is a cool teacher. There aren't alot of points to earn in the class, but I went to class, took notes and did ok. I would recommend his philosophy 101 class to anyone.

Prof. Hubin's class was a pretty good one. There's a midterm, a final, and an 8-10 page term paper. A lot of the material is pretty boring. Be ready to spend an entire semester comparing axiological and deontological ethical theories. Hubin definitely encourages his students to think for themselves, but he makes his opinions known.

It won't be the easiest thing you have ever done in your life, nor the hardest, but I'd recommend Dr. Hubin for any course he teaches. Especially since this particular course is required of all Philosophy majors, I'd definitely take it with him. Very nice guy and extremely clear and helpful.

Great teacher. Took him for political philosophy. He really cares, enjoys teaching, understands the material without tilting the discussions towards his own personal position (i.e. is honest with the material and treats it neutrally), and does a great job of presenting it all sides of a topic. There should be more  like him. Good chess player too.
Entertaining, knows how to get side tracked easily, yet, bubbly and refreshing.

Prof. Hubin was awesome! He teaches with enthusiasm and passion which is a plus. He is one of the best instructors i've ever had :) The course was difficult but he give you plenty of chances to raise your grade if need be.

Don Hubin is one of the best professors I have ever hard.  He is a genuinely nice guy and loves to teach (or does a damn fine job of faking it). His lectures are entertaining and he makes it very easy to prepare for tests. Keep up with the readings, do your term paper early and you are good to go. He also likes to talk a lot about cougars. :)

Took his class for Fall 08' quarter.  It is a pretty interesting course if you are in to thinking.  He is very approachable and a genuinely nice guy.  He gives outlines on what he wants you to know for his exams.  I thought his exams were on the tougher side because of the T/F questions that are worded tricky.  Fortunately, he give extra credit.
Fabulous teacher - would take another class any time

Dr. Hubin is great. As a freshman, I was always worried how college classes would actually work. The way professor Hubin presents the material is freshman-friendly way so that success is attainable if you put the effort into it.

Dr. Hubin seriously has to be one of the nicest professors at Ohio State. Attend lectures, pay attention, read, and ask questions and you'll do great! Now, he isn't a push over but he's always willing to make sure you understand the material. I highly recommend taking his class!

Great teacher. Really cares about his students and is extremely passionate about the subject matter. Go to class and exam review, check his notes on Carmen, and you'll be fine. Book useful only for reading check quizzes.

Dr. Hubin's great. Like the other review said, *crystal* clear. Helpful handouts. Pretty funny, too. The only drawback was the class getting a bit sidetracked at times, but still... highly recommended.

Crystal clear, always willing to discuss further (though this can get him in trouble towards the end of the quarter, approachable. Do the reading, take notes (including on the innumerable and immensely helpful handouts), and PAY ATTENTION! You'll have a blast.

Very nice guy and willling to help students. lectures can be boring. go to recitation and you'll do good. i suggest Kevin as a TA. reviews are helpful and exams are multiple choice, t/f, and an essay. only 3 exams per quarter.
awesome teacher, lectures can sometimes be a little boring with the powerpoints but over all very interesting subject matter. extremely nice guy.
Keeps the lectures interesting. Obviously cares a great deal about the subject matter, teaching it well, and his students. Definitely suggest this class. Get Kevin as your TA.
Hubins hot. take the class

Hubin is a great teacher.  He's invariably clear and engaging in lecture and gives extensive exposition on his handouts, so you spend your time actually thinking about the material instead of just trying to understand it.  I took 431 only b/c it was required for the major, but ended up loving it.  Definitely one of my favorites in the department.
i love this man! he is so enthusiastic. he is always smiling. he doesnt lecture he talks.
Makes outlines and handouts that make it easier to pay attention to discussion instead of just taking notes, exams could be hard but if you prepared well they weren't too bad.
No Comments
fun, good stories for examples, flexible about grading if you talk to him.
Lots of notes but just having them isn't good enough... exams in 430 were killer... but he was very entertaining and passionate

Don is one of my favorite professors @ OSU, he truly cares for his students and the subject matter, a lot of power point, tons of notes but great explination of everything, tries to add humor to everything to which is a bonus.
great professor, was a retake of the class for me and I went from an E to a B with Hubin.  Don is very helpful and fair on exams and other work.
Don is a great guy and the class was very helpful and interesting. My only problem was the over-useage of power point for notes

Prof. Kerr is a generally nice person, though I often think her opinions are a bit swayed. Dealing with conceptions of sex/love, her views center around ideals of  feminism and liberal sexual values, so you must be considerate when taking tests.  All in all not a bad course, but concepts are a bit basic and lectures are boring/uninformative.

Allison is an amazing teacher. She was very helpful and I couldn't have lasses without her and her TA Tim. I had a tough time with the material but that wasn't her fault. If you thought she was rude then you were PROBABLY talking in class because she only got  upset when people were talking during class. Smoking hott as well.

I felt Allison's class was poor all around. The syllabus didn't list any reading dates, and the course sacrificed any potential philosophical depth by constantly fixating on the feminist movement. Like many other professors at OSU, her strict attendance policy is probably the only thing keeping people in class.

Her course material is difficult, but she's very clear and gives a lot of examples.  I thought her class was a lot of fun, even though I had a hard time with the subject matter.  She was also very helpful and friendly during office hours.

Course material DID NOT come easily to me, but somehow I managed an A. We were still learning new stuff the class before the final as a result of her being sick one day and then a snow day. She did however offer a study session the night before the final which was helpful. She gets really mad if you talk during class, even if it's about PHIL.

She's a fantastic teacher. She makes this class extremely fun and interesting and engages us in our work. She's wonderful when someone makes a mistake, and we take the time to go through it and explain why it's wrong. She usually thanks people when they make mistakes, and invites us to argue our points if we think we're right. Take her if you can!
She's fun and her mohawk is hot!
Very good teacher!

She makes what would be a very boring topic actually interesting and applicable to everyday life.  Her class is entertaining, and she obviously works hard to help the students understand the material.
She wasn't helpful.  She talked down to people.  She answered questions incorrectly.  I thought she was rude.
The class was boring, but Alison was really helpful. She's a great TA.
She's incredible.
Extremely helpful and hot.
Alison gave me so much help.  Met with me multiple times.  She is so sweet.  She spent hours with me.  Alison helped me understand logic.  Without her, I would've failed.

Alison goes ABOVE AND BEYOND the call of duty for TA's. Very kind and patient.She met with me outside of class to go over anything she could. She also gave me strategies and tips to get the most points on the tests.Excellent TA!

She was extremely helpful for me.  She went out of her way to meet with me and to respond to my emails.  I would not have done as well in the course without her help.  She explained everything far more clearly than the professor.
She isn't helpful at all. I don't understand how anyone could come to that conclusion. Trust me, there are better teachers in the Phil department
She's great.  Very helpful and engaged.
No Comments
No Comments
i was looking around here and i noticed her name, i forgot about her i had her last quarter(winter) she is miserable. never take a class if she teaches it.
I agree with the first person. She wasn't helpful at all and talked down to everyone.

Alison is useless as a TA. When we had our midterm review, she answered a few questions incorrectly (which thankfully I discovered later before the midterm). She is rude, and had a bad case of "power trip". If she ends up teaching her own class, I would highly advise to avoid her at all costs.

Kate is great. She's very clear. Most points come from daily participation. She will cancel class or excuse you for interviews, career fairs, etc. Very fair. Tests are tough, but exactly what you would expect. Gives extra credit. She's a little awkward, but it's a nice awkward.
She did an amazing job building bridges between my interests and the class. Also, she is kinda hot compared to other profs at OSU.
Dr. MacFarland is hard but fair. I learned alot in this class.

Kate is an excellent professor because she is genuinely interested in students' learning. She does a fantastic job applying philosophy to engineering and making the class as interesting as possible for people who probably aren't too interested in philosophy. Come to lectures prepared to participate in class discussions.

Professor McFarland was a great teacher.  I learned a lot about Engineering Ethics and enjoyed her occasional snarky comments.  Her sharp outfits make me want to build bridges over rivers in Ashtabulia.  That are up to code.
What a delight. I'd walk a decent distance to enjoy one of professor mcfarland's lectures. Occasionally she'd smile at me and it would make my day.
Kate had a lot of helpful handouts and magnets.
Kate's incredible hotness made what would normally have been a boring class into a highlight of my day.
I didn't really pay that much attention because I just kept thinking about how hot she was. Math isn't really my thing, but Kate made it interesting.

She was difficult to understand in class and did not deem it necessary to make time to discuss difficult points. Additionally, meeting with her during office hours was awkward and she was not helpful.

The material for this course is considerably uninteresting but what frustrated many was the disconnect between the book, study guides, and then the actual exam. The grade scheme is three exams, that's it. We ended up with a30% curve(at least) because the average grades were F's. The instructor did not change anything  to improve grades despite this

He expects students to know the material, but he's a really cool guy. He's very knowledgeable about the subject and you will learn. He's also somewhat lenient on deadlines and has moved class outside!

Definitely got me interested in the class, I wasn't even originally interested in the class at all, but he seemed to know just about all of the material. Grading was hard though, but i still enjoyed learning the material.

I had him at Columbus State he was hard to understand. Didn't explain things well. No one could read his hand writing. He was unprofessional. He graded rediculously hard. My advice is to choose another class.

He teaches the GEC class like everyone is majoring in it. He gives out WAY too much information. He gives pop quizzes too and doesn't post his incredibly boring powerpoints. The class average was a 44% for the first one, and he didn't even curve it. My advice; pick a different class.
great lectures!

Hardest GEC I have ever taken. The exams were extremely difficult and included examples we never went over in class. He wasn't willing to help students and the grading was ridiculously subjective. 2 TAs and grading was different for each. I don't recommend this class to anyone who cares even the tiniest bit about their GPA.
Way too hard for a GEC. Class was interesting but didn't really seem to prepare me for exams. I studied but scored much lower than I normally do.

One of the worst professors I have ever had. The exams are extremely hard, being filled with unfamiliar material. I studied the notes and textbook and still failed every exam, which he had to curve dramatically. He knows the material, but has trouble teaching it. It's definitely a difficult class for a GEC.

Reallt friendly guy. Knows his stuff really well. Kind of arrogant, but overall I enjoyed this class as it was very relaxed. And explored great ideas. I think Dai was the perfect 101 teacher. Exams are super hard though.
Excellent teacher, I would recommend him. Just be warned he comes off a little arrogant, but he's such a great teacher it doesn't matter.
Good lectures, but I found him a little arrogant. I wouldn't take another class he taught.
really interesting.. great teaching style.. encouraged discussion.. and hottttt
